> >whoa, hold on there a second.  To jump to the conclusion that anyone who
> >supports deportation of illegal immigrants or strict limits and
> enforcement
> >on immigration is racist really is non-sequitur.  Have you considered
> that
> >someone could want illegal immigrants punished as criminals because,
> under
> >the law of the land, they are in fact criminals?  That's no different
> than
> >desiring the enforcement of law in general, and is hardly a fault.
> >
> >I'm originally from Houston, TX, the third largest city in the US by
> >population.  There are now more hispanics living in the city than whites,
> >many of whom are perfectly legal.  Most of the illegal workers don't
> cause
> >problems, though there is a higher crime rate in predominately hispanic
> >neighborhoods than in predominantly white and asian neighborhoods.  I
> know
> >firsthand, as I'm sure many people here and any inhabitants of L.A. also
> >do,
> >how massive the impact to the workforce would be if every illegal
> hispanic
> >were deported.  These people maintain our roads and utilities, take out
> our
> >garbage, build our buildings, and give $3 haircuts from their unlicensed
> >salon that are often better than the $30 haircut down the road, to name a
> >few things.  Having seen and lived with all this, I have something of a
> >mixed view about the situation as a whole.
> >
> >Importantly, I want to make it abundantly clear that I think the terms of
> >labor for many immigrants is terrible and wrong, and I think it is the
> >moral
> >duty of the law to protect the rights of all workers, legal and
> illegal.  A
> >starvation wage for dangerous work is never appropriate in a society that
> >can easily afford to pay workers more.  Sadly, these conditions are still
> >vastly better than the opportunities in many immigrants' native lands, so
> >they continue to come across the border and endure mistreatment and
> >underpayment as workers.  But this doesn't mean that labor abuse is
> >justified.
> >
> >The other side of the coin is the impact that massive and unregulated
> >immigration would have on the economy and actual Citizens of the
> US.  Face
> >it: the government of the US has a higher responsibility to rule in the
> >interests of its own citizens than it does to providing opportunity to
> the
> >citizens of other countries.  Indeed, after a fashion nearly everyone on
> >this continent can be considered an immigrant at some point in history,
> but
> >citizenship remains a clear and valid delineation as far as determining
> >responsibility of a government.  A healthy immigrant population is good
> for
> >the country, as it does provide a vital source of labor, but excessive
> >immigration won't be supportable.  There is a finite amount of work
> >available, but unlimited potential for population growth if we simply
> open
> >the borders, and eventually you reach a critical point where immigrants
> >cease to be a benefit.
> >
> >I don't claim to have an answer to the problem.  But I do have a very
> hard
> >time being labeled as Racist because I think that unregulated, illegal
> >immigration should be stopped, and that some penalty should exist for
> >people
> >who commit crimes even though the law in question badly needs reform.
> >
> >My $0.02

Subject: Re: [sfraves] The truth about 4/29

you're describing the differences in energy output based on the 
air:fuel ratio.  The most power is released when the mixture is 
slightly lean of stoichiometric.  If the tanker had exploded instead 
of burned, most of the maze would've been leveled.


sarilion

At 11:53 AM 5/3/2007, Nathan Seven wrote:
>Huh-
>
>I would think that this tactic wouldn't work so well.
>Any teenager with $50 and a bit of chemistry can build a device large
>enough to stick to the side of a tanker, rupture it, and ignite it.
>But what is the damage done?
>Driving through a fireball @ 70mph is not even a source of stress.
>Much more dangerous is the chance of hitting the truck/trailer that
>has now overturned.
>So- a normal truck, loaded with a bunch of big pipes or something
>would be a more effective weapon against soft human targets in their
>cars.
>Gasoline and most other liquified chemicals in tanker trucks don't
>provide their own oxygen and do not detonate- they burn, rather than
>explode.
>To get a good explosion out of these things you need to BLEVE them-
>This is when- say- a rail car filled with gas overturns and sprouts a
>small leak at the top-
>A little gas comes out and burns, but because it's overturned that
>little fire goes up- and weakens one area of the metal the tank is
>made of, simultaneously heating up the contents of the tank.
>It'll sit like that for an hour- weakening the metal, building up
>internal pressure...
>Then when the pressure and the weakness meet in some sort of unholy
>coup de grace, hell breaks loose and the shit hits the fan.
>These are among the largest non-nuclear explosions that mankind has
>ever produced.
>
>In summary- see a tanker truck roll over, tear itself apart, and
>burst in to flame?
>Keep driving.
>See a tanker truck rolled over, still intact, with a small fire?
>RUN LIKE FUCKING HELL
>

>>On May 3, 2007, at 9:14 AM, Will Penna wrote:
>>
>>>Mattier & Ross in this morning's SFChron: Seems that all 12 lugs on
>>>the wheels of a tanker carrying 8600 gals of gas recently came off
>>>in Golden Gate Park. Coincidence or conspiracy? You be the judge.
>>>
>>>http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/05/03/
>>>BAGFLPJME830.DTL
>>>
>>>MATIER AND ROSS
>>>Owner of tanker that lost wheels in Golden Gate Park is
>>>investigating accident
>>>Phillip Matier, Andrew Ross
>>>Thursday, May 3, 2007
>>>
>>>Officials of the fuel-hauling company whose gasoline tanker truck
>>>lost a pair of wheels in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park last week
>>>said Wednesday they are stumped over what caused the dangerous
>>>mishap -- but they are investigating the possibility that someone
>>>tampered with the vehicle.
>>>
>>>The truck, which belongs to KAG West of West Sacramento, lost the
>>>left front wheels off the tanker on Park Presidio Drive the night
>>>of April 26, while it was heading for a Shell station with 8,600
>>>gallons of gas. San Francisco police didn't take a report because
>>>no one was hurt in the accident, but a Municipal Railway mechanic
>>>whose private car was hit by one of the tires, Michael Cheney, said
>>>all 10 lug nuts on the wheels had come off.
>>>
>>>Bruce Redmon, KAG West's safety director, said the 2-year-old truck
>>>had undergone a routine inspection that night before leaving the
>>>company's fueling terminal in Martinez. The inspection included
>>>checking the lug nuts on all the wheels, Redmon said.
>>>
>>>"They (the trucks) are checked daily, and this was no exception,''
>>>Redmon said.
>>>
>>>He said he'd been in the trucking business 30 years and this was
>>>the first time he'd ever heard of a set of tanker wheels simply
>>>falling off. He said he couldn't predict how long the investigation
>>>will take to complete.
>>>
>>>"It could be today, or 30 days from today, because we want the
>>>conclusion to be correct,'' he said. As for the possibility of
>>>tampering, he said: "There is a chance.''
>>>
>>>Cheney, who works on Muni buses, said that in his opinion, the lug
>>>nuts did not appear to have been stripped. That suggests the nuts
>>>either weren't properly tightened or they were intentionally
>>>loosened, he said.
>>>
>>>So far, police have not gotten involved in the investigation. The
>>>police officers who responded to the accident were there to make
>>>sure the truck driver and the drivers of the two cars hit by the
>>>wheels exchanged information for insurance purposes, and to direct
>>>traffic around the scene. The California Highway Patrol, which
>>>regulates tanker trucks on the highways, was never called.
>>>
>>>Even though the incident happened on a state highway -- Park
>>>Presidio is part of Highway 1 -- "there has to be a fatality,
>>>injury or tow-away (for the CHP to become involved), and this did
>>>not comply with any of those,'' Redmon said.
>>>
>>>He said that both the driver and his company, which operates 225
>>>fuel trucks in California, Arizona and Nevada, have "an exemplary
>>>record.''
>>>
>>>CHP safety officials said a review of KAG West records shows the
>>>company's Martinez terminal received an "unsatisfactory'' report
>>>for what was described only as "inadequate repair equipment'' just
>>>after the firm acquired the facility from another operator in 2003.
>>>But the company was given a clean bill of health on a return visit
>>>four months later, and again last year.
>>>
>>>Highway Patrol records show that KAG West trucks have been issued
>>>17 citations in California since Jan. 11, mostly for basic
>>>equipment violations. But according to Greg Bragg, manager of motor
>>>carrier safety for the CHP, given the number of trucks KAG West
>>>operates, "that level of citations is actually a very low rate.''
>>>
>>>All aboard: Everyone is working in overdrive to get the collapsed
>>>portion of the MacArthur Maze fixed -- and to get their share of
>>>political face time in as well.
>>>And, from what we're told, the effort to generate attention is also
>>>generating a bit of friction within the Bay Area's heavily
>>>Democratic political family.
>>>
>>>Rep. Ellen Tauscher of Walnut Creek is arranging a big helicopter
>>>flyover of the accident scene Friday morning, with Caltrans
>>>Director Will Kempton, Rep. Barbara Lee of Oakland and Rep. James
>>>Oberstar of Minnesota, chairman of the House Transportation and
>>>Infrastructure Committee, along for the ride.
>>>
>>>Not to be outdone, Sen. Barbara Boxer is planning her own private
>>>briefing and tour Friday -- accompanied by U.S. Transportation
>>>Secretary Mary Peters and Caltrans' local boss, Bijan Sartipi.
>>>
>>>Boxer plans to finish late in the morning with a big media event
>>>near the maze, to which she has invited Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger,
>>>San Francisco Mayor Gavin Newsom, Oakland Mayor Ron Dellums, Lee
>>>and Tauscher.
>>>
>>>And what about Tauscher's helicopter ride, departing from SFO at
>>>10:15 a.m. -- less than an hour before the scheduled press
>>>conference?
>>>
>>>"We are not partaking in the helicopter tour,'' Boxer spokeswoman
>>>Natalie Ravitz said. "We are told we can survey the damage right
>>>there on the scene.''
>>>
>>>Fine, Tauscher's people insist. But just for the record, they say
>>>they were planning the maze flyover even before Sunday's collapse,
>>>as part of an effort to scrape up more federal dollars for Bay Area
>>>transit.
>>>
>>>Bottom line, said Tauscher spokesman Kevin Lawlor: "It's tough to
>>>get everyone together with their schedules, but hopefully we can at
>>>least get everyone in one place for the press conference.''
>>>
>>>No doubt, no doubt.
>>>

>>>dancing George Bush caption contest. Vote for the best option for
>>>dealing with the MacArthur Maze mess. Check out the bricks and
>>>kisses in feedback. And read the Extra, Extra, Extra musings and
>>>insights of friends including Rich "Big Vinny'' Lieberman and The
>>>Chronicle's Carla Marinucci and Don "Bad Reporter" Asmussen.
>>>
>>>Chronicle columnists Phillip Matier and Andrew Ross regularly
>>>appear Sundays, Mondays and Wednesdays. Phil can be seen on CBS 5-
>>>TV morning and evening news. Matier can also be heard on KCBS radio
>>>Monday to Friday at 7:50 a.m. and 5:50 p.m. Got a tip? Call them at
>>>(415) 777-8815 or drop them an e-mail at
>>>matierandross@sfchronicle.com.

>will still want to come here if they're able because their perception of 
>the
>country won't reflect the economic reality.  Excessive immigration will, at
>some point, become a problem once the labor available is massively greater
>than the demand for work.  I'm not being a bigot and saying "them illegals
>is sucking up our resources," because the same problems would arise out of
>massive unemployment no matter what the citizenship or nationality of the
>unemployed.  It seems to me that there is danger in artificially inflating
>the unemployment rate via unregulated immigration, but the danger is the
>same as a naturally growing unemployment rate.  Our government does, I
>think, have a clear responsibility to prevent negative consequences to the
>economy arising from immigration, which means that a balance needs to be
>found between the benefits of immigrant labor and the need to maintain a
>stable unemployment rate (which is damn hard to do, which is why we still
>have problems).
>
>Maybe I'm misinterpreting your statement and reply.  But I feel that I'm
>being called a bigot, or lumped in with bigots, when even someone who
>disagrees with my conclusions can see that racial hatred is no part of my
>rational process at all.  I'd love to be told I'm incorrect in this regard.
>
>On 5/3/07, Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>>
>>So put blame squarely on the shoulders of the folks who exploit these
>>illegal workers. If companies in the USA didn't hire them and there was no
>>money to be made, do you think they'd still come en masse? They come here
>>for work, for opportunities to make money, to better their lives...kinda
>>like the people who founded this country.
>>
>>So go ahead and charge every farm/horse farm/construction
>>company/landscaping company, etc. that hires these people...do you think
>>that'd go over too well? Do you have any idea of the negative impact that
>>would have on our country's economy???
>>
>>See - it's not just as cut and dry as "get all them' thar illegals out o'
>>my
>>country!"
>>
>>I don't advocate us just letting in folks willy nilly for the record - but
>>when people try and push the whole "illegal immigrants are terrorists"
>>bullshit (how many people from 9/11 were Mexican?) or that they "suck up
>>all
>>our resources" (kinda like illegal wars in the middle east sucks up our
>>resources) - it just gets under my skin.
>>
>>
>>
>> >From: "Matthew Johnson" <prayformojo524@gmail.com>
>> >To: "Van Mundegaarde" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
>> >CC: tsheets@saturn5.com, scosol@scosol.org, hso@hsomusic.com,
>> >sfraves@hyperreal.org
>> >Subject: Re: [sfraves] LAPD fires rubber bullets into immigration 
>>protest
>> >crowd
>> >Date: Thu, 3 May 2007 16:11:10 -0700
>> >
>> >whoa, hold on there a second.  To jump to the conclusion that anyone who
>> >supports deportation of illegal immigrants or strict limits and
>>enforcement
>> >on immigration is racist really is non-sequitur.  Have you considered
>>that
>> >someone could want illegal immigrants punished as criminals because,
>>under
>> >the law of the land, they are in fact criminals?  That's no different
>>than
>> >desiring the enforcement of law in general, and is hardly a fault.
>> >
>> >I'm originally from Houston, TX, the third largest city in the US by
>> >population.  There are now more hispanics living in the city than 
>>whites,
>> >many of whom are perfectly legal.  Most of the illegal workers don't
>>cause
>> >problems, though there is a higher crime rate in predominately hispanic
>> >neighborhoods than in predominantly white and asian neighborhoods.  I
>>know
>> >firsthand, as I'm sure many people here and any inhabitants of L.A. also
>> >do,
>> >how massive the impact to the workforce would be if every illegal
>>hispanic
>> >were deported.  These people maintain our roads and utilities, take out
>>our
>> >garbage, build our buildings, and give $3 haircuts from their unlicensed
>> >salon that are often better than the $30 haircut down the road, to name 
>>a
>> >few things.  Having seen and lived with all this, I have something of a
>> >mixed view about the situation as a whole.
>> >
>> >Importantly, I want to make it abundantly clear that I think the terms 
>>of
>> >labor for many immigrants is terrible and wrong, and I think it is the
>> >moral
>> >duty of the law to protect the rights of all workers, legal and
>>illegal.  A
>> >starvation wage for dangerous work is never appropriate in a society 
>>that
>> >can easily afford to pay workers more.  Sadly, these conditions are 
>>still
>> >vastly better than the opportunities in many immigrants' native lands, 
>>so
>> >they continue to come across the border and endure mistreatment and
>> >underpayment as workers.  But this doesn't mean that labor abuse is
>> >justified.
>> >
>> >The other side of the coin is the impact that massive and unregulated
>> >immigration would have on the economy and actual Citizens of the
>>US.  Face
>> >it: the government of the US has a higher responsibility to rule in the
>> >interests of its own citizens than it does to providing opportunity to
>>the
>> >citizens of other countries.  Indeed, after a fashion nearly everyone on
>> >this continent can be considered an immigrant at some point in history,
>>but
>> >citizenship remains a clear and valid delineation as far as determining
>> >responsibility of a government.  A healthy immigrant population is good
>>for
>> >the country, as it does provide a vital source of labor, but excessive
>> >immigration won't be supportable.  There is a finite amount of work
>> >available, but unlimited potential for population growth if we simply
>>open
>> >the borders, and eventually you reach a critical point where immigrants
>> >cease to be a benefit.
>> >
>> >I don't claim to have an answer to the problem.  But I do have a very
>>hard
>> >time being labeled as Racist because I think that unregulated, illegal
>> >immigration should be stopped, and that some penalty should exist for
>> >people
>> >who commit crimes even though the law in question badly needs reform.
>> >
>> >My $0.02
>> >
>> >On 5/3/07, Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>> >>
>> >>People who advocate deportation of all illegals are just ignorant of 
>>the
>> >>fact that they contribute so much to our society. Not to mention if
>>you're
>> >>going to start deporting illegals all willy nilly, does that mean all 
>>of
>> >>my
>> >>Italian relatives that came to this country "without papers" (this is
>> >>where
>> >>the term WOP came from) should all be deported too? How about the Jews?
>> >>Irish?
>> >>
>> >>For that matter, should we deport all the British descendants of the
>> >>original Puritans seeing as how they stole the land from the Native
>> >>Americans?
>> >>
>> >>Yea exactly.
>> >>
>> >>I wish people would just admit they're racist and don't want them dirty
>> >>brown skinned folks here in the good ol' US of A...
>> >>
>> >>NASCAR  AND GUNS FOR EVERYONE!!!
>> >>
>> >>
>> >>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fwd: Love Is All Around

Personally I'd say that there was at least some likelihood of confusion between "Love Festival" and "Lovefest" which is the standard for trademarks.  But that would only ever be an issue if you had to litigate I think.  And as long as no one complains, there is no issue.  Full speed ahead!

J.C. posted a link to a registered mark for "Love Fest" but I think that only protects a specific rendering of the term shown in the image on the page.   So if I am right, as long as you don't copy this exact mark or make yours very similar looking there's no problem here.  IANAL.

On the other hand either of these folks likely could give you a hard time if they really wanted to.  They might lose in the end, but you'd be forced to spend money defending your use of the term and associated marks.

I've dealt with this exact scenario in the software business where a party makes unfounded trademark accusations that need to be defended.  Sometimes it seems easier to just get a new "clean" name, rather than spending thosuands in attorney's fees defending the questioned name but it also depends on how much equity you feel you've built in the brand.  

FWIW I was threatened with trademark litigation over both my company's name and a producgt name.  I might have been able to defend these cases and win, but it would have cost probably $25-$50,000 to do it in each case.  

Peace, 
 
Peter

>>> I don't advocate us just letting in folks willy nilly for the =20
>>> record - but
>>> when people try and push the whole "illegal immigrants are =20
>>> terrorists"
>>> bullshit (how many people from 9/11 were Mexican?) or that they =20
>>> "suck up
>>> all
>>> our resources" (kinda like illegal wars in the middle east sucks =20
>>> up our
>>> resources) - it just gets under my skin.

>>> US by
>>> >population.  There are now more hispanics living in the city =20
>>> than whites,
>>> >many of whom are perfectly legal.  Most of the illegal workers =20
>>> don't
>>> cause
>>> >problems, though there is a higher crime rate in predominately =20
>>> hispanic
>>> >neighborhoods than in predominantly white and asian =20
>>> neighborhoods.  I
>>> know
>>> >firsthand, as I'm sure many people here and any inhabitants of =20
>>> L.A. also
>>> >do,
>>> >how massive the impact to the workforce would be if every illegal
>>> hispanic
>>> >were deported.  These people maintain our roads and utilities, =20
>>> take out
>>> our
>>> >garbage, build our buildings, and give $3 haircuts from their =20
>>> unlicensed
>>> >salon that are often better than the $30 haircut down the road, =20
>>> to name a
>>> >few things.  Having seen and lived with all this, I have =20
>>> something of a
>>> >mixed view about the situation as a whole.
>>> >
>>> >Importantly, I want to make it abundantly clear that I think the =20=

>>> terms of
>>> >labor for many immigrants is terrible and wrong, and I think it =20
>>> is the
>>> >moral
>>> >duty of the law to protect the rights of all workers, legal and
>>> illegal.  A
>>> >starvation wage for dangerous work is never appropriate in a =20
>>> society that
>>> >can easily afford to pay workers more.  Sadly, these conditions =20
>>> are still
>>> >vastly better than the opportunities in many immigrants' native =20
>>> lands, so
>>> >they continue to come across the border and endure mistreatment and
>>> >underpayment as workers.  But this doesn't mean that labor abuse is
>>> >justified.
>>> >
>>> >The other side of the coin is the impact that massive and =20
>>> unregulated
>>> >immigration would have on the economy and actual Citizens of the
>>> US.  Face
>>> >it: the government of the US has a higher responsibility to rule =20=

>>> in the
>>> >interests of its own citizens than it does to providing =20
>>> opportunity to
>>> the
>>> >citizens of other countries.  Indeed, after a fashion nearly =20
>>> everyone on
>>> >this continent can be considered an immigrant at some point in =20
>>> history,
>>> but
>>> >citizenship remains a clear and valid delineation as far as =20
>>> determining
>>> >responsibility of a government.  A healthy immigrant population =20
>>> is good
>>> for
>>> >the country, as it does provide a vital source of labor, but =20
>>> excessive
>>> >immigration won't be supportable.  There is a finite amount of work
>>> >available, but unlimited potential for population growth if we =20
>>> simply
>>> open
>>> >the borders, and eventually you reach a critical point where =20
>>> immigrants
>>> >cease to be a benefit.
>>> >
>>> >I don't claim to have an answer to the problem.  But I do have a =20=

>>> very
>>> hard
>>> >time being labeled as Racist because I think that unregulated, =20
>>> illegal
>>> >immigration should be stopped, and that some penalty should =20
>>> exist for
>>> >people
>>> >who commit crimes even though the law in question badly needs =20
>>> reform.
>>> >

>>>From: "Matthew Johnson" <prayformojo524@gmail.com>
>>>To: "Van Mundegaarde" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
>>>CC: tsheets@saturn5.com, scosol@scosol.org, hso@hsomusic.com,  
>>>sfraves@hyperreal.org
>>>Subject: Re: [sfraves] LAPD fires rubber bullets into immigration  
>>>protest crowd
>>>Date: Thu, 3 May 2007 18:40:10 -0700
>>>
>>>Did I say anything different than what you said in your first  paragraph? 
>>>  I
>>>didn't blame immigrants for wanting to come (because there is  money 
>>>here),
>>>and I also denounced unfair exploitation of workers.  Arresting  everyone 
>>>who
>>>employs them isn't the answer, but I also never claimed that blanket
>>>deportation is good either.
>>>
>>>You have to remember, though, that even if there isn't all that  much 
>>>money,
>>>or opportunity, for additional workers that are not already here,  
>>>immigrants
>>>will still want to come here if they're able because their  perception of 
>>>the
>>>country won't reflect the economic reality.  Excessive immigration  will, 
>>>at
>>>some point, become a problem once the labor available is massively  
>>>greater
>>>than the demand for work.  I'm not being a bigot and saying "them  
>>>illegals
>>>is sucking up our resources," because the same problems would  arise out 
>>>of
>>>massive unemployment no matter what the citizenship or nationality  of 
>>>the
>>>unemployed.  It seems to me that there is danger in artificially  
>>>inflating
>>>the unemployment rate via unregulated immigration, but the danger  is the
>>>same as a naturally growing unemployment rate.  Our government  does, I
>>>think, have a clear responsibility to prevent negative  consequences to 
>>>the
>>>economy arising from immigration, which means that a balance needs  to be
>>>found between the benefits of immigrant labor and the need to  maintain a
>>>stable unemployment rate (which is damn hard to do, which is why  we 
>>>still
>>>have problems).
>>>
>>>Maybe I'm misinterpreting your statement and reply.  But I feel  that I'm
>>>being called a bigot, or lumped in with bigots, when even someone who
>>>disagrees with my conclusions can see that racial hatred is no  part of 
>>>my
>>>rational process at all.  I'd love to be told I'm incorrect in  this 
>>>regard.
>>>
>>>On 5/3/07, Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>>>>
>>>>So put blame squarely on the shoulders of the folks who exploit  these
>>>>illegal workers. If companies in the USA didn't hire them and  there was 
>>>>no

>>>>here
>>>>for work, for opportunities to make money, to better their  
>>>>lives...kinda
>>>>like the people who founded this country.
>>>>

>>>>company/landscaping company, etc. that hires these people...do  you 
>>>>think
>>>>that'd go over too well? Do you have any idea of the negative  impact 
>>>>that
>>>>would have on our country's economy???
>>>>
>>>>See - it's not just as cut and dry as "get all them' thar  illegals out 
>>>>o'
>>>>my
>>>>country!"

>>>>I don't advocate us just letting in folks willy nilly for the  record - 
>>>>but

>>>>bullshit (how many people from 9/11 were Mexican?) or that they  "suck 
>>>>up
>>>>all
>>>>our resources" (kinda like illegal wars in the middle east sucks  up our

>>>> >population.  There are now more hispanics living in the city  than 
>>>>whites,
>>>> >many of whom are perfectly legal.  Most of the illegal workers  don't
>>>>cause
>>>> >problems, though there is a higher crime rate in predominately  
>>>>hispanic
>>>> >neighborhoods than in predominantly white and asian  neighborhoods.  I
>>>>know
>>>> >firsthand, as I'm sure many people here and any inhabitants of  L.A. 
>>>>also

>>>>hispanic

>>>>name a

>>>>a

>>>> >Importantly, I want to make it abundantly clear that I think the  
>>>>terms of
>>>> >labor for many immigrants is terrible and wrong, and I think it  is 
>>>>the
>>>> >moral
>>>> >duty of the law to protect the rights of all workers, legal and
>>>>illegal.  A
>>>> >starvation wage for dangerous work is never appropriate in a  society 
>>>>that
>>>> >can easily afford to pay workers more.  Sadly, these conditions  are 
>>>>still
>>>> >vastly better than the opportunities in many immigrants' native  
>>>>lands, so
>>>> >they continue to come across the border and endure mistreatment and
>>>> >underpayment as workers.  But this doesn't mean that labor abuse is
>>>> >justified.

>>>>US.  Face
>>>> >it: the government of the US has a higher responsibility to rule  in

>>>>the
>>>> >citizens of other countries.  Indeed, after a fashion nearly  everyone 
>>>>on
>>>> >this continent can be considered an immigrant at some point in  
>>>>history,
>>>>but
>>>> >citizenship remains a clear and valid delineation as far as  
>>>>determining
>>>> >responsibility of a government.  A healthy immigrant population  is 
>>>>good
>>>>for
>>>> >the country, as it does provide a vital source of labor, but  
>>>>excessive
>>>> >immigration won't be supportable.  There is a finite amount of work
>>>> >available, but unlimited potential for population growth if we  simply
>>>>open
>>>> >the borders, and eventually you reach a critical point where  
>>>>immigrants
>>>> >cease to be a benefit.
>>>> >
>>>> >I don't claim to have an answer to the problem.  But I do have a  very

>>>> >time being labeled as Racist because I think that unregulated,

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: robbery at afterglow

Hey folks,

Sorry for the forwarded message, but a small business owner on
Telegraph had her store robbed this morning and I would like to ask
y'all to keep an eye out for her designs. She was robbed of more than
$12,000 in wares, which she and other designers all made by hand.

I find it disgusting & heartbreaking that someone would rob a store
like hers. These artists work so hard to support themselves.

/end rant

*********************************************

Amy M. Cools
afterglow / AC Clothing and Bags
4233 Telegraph Ave Oakland CA 94609
 510.654.7514 www.acclothingandbags.com

 Hello everyone.
I'm sad to announce that my darling little shop afterglow was robbed
early this morning, sometime between 12:00 (I looked at my shop while
going home last night) and this morning at about 6:00, when my
neighbor arrived at his dental lab & heard the alarm. The thieves
hacked thru the thick wood door to get to the deadbolt, which they
pried apart enough to kick the door in.
The thieves made off with a huge amount of clothing. They didn't touch
the jewelry or accessories, tee shirts, or a rack with my newest
pieces, Donna Lou's new pants, or Camilla's bicycle dresses. They
targeted the big rack that included the main bulk of my designs and
the collections of these designers, over 150 pieces in all & totalling
over $12,500 in retail value:
Donna Lou (except for the sailor pants), Nicacelly, and Super Sugar
Ray Ray, and the one remaining tunic by Porcelynne.
For you ladies, don't worry: your pieces are covered by my insurance,
and you will all be taken care of.
My landlord immediately installed a metal sleeve around the door where
the locks are, and will install yet another deadbolt & possibly a
roll-down door, so I don't expect this to happen again.
If you could look out for anyone trying to sell my designs or the
other designs, who you don't know, or can pass this email along to
anyone who may hear or see anything, I'd really appreciate it. All
items have sewn labels (mine is AC, the others are as mentioned above)
and are tagged.
This is a tough blow to my little business, but I'm even tougher, so
you can bet I'll be back in full force before too long, & I'm doing
all I can to recover the lost afterglow collection.
Yours, Amy


--=20
Main Entry: 1ta=B7la
Pronunciation: 't=E4-l&
Function: noun
Etymology: Sanskrit tAla, literally, hand-clapping
: one of the ancient traditional rhythmic patterns of Indian music --
compare RAGA

Y'all ready for another round?  Kontrol #23 is all systems go!

Yes, the lineup is sick, per usual.  Guthrie Miller, the main record buyer
at Tweekin', has been added to the bill for a special sunrise closing set.
Stephen Beaupr=E9 has promised to BRING IT. And seriously, you really don't
want to miss M-nus' new star Ambivalent, who will be on at 3am. We had a
chance to sneak-preview his set and it is fucking NASTY!  It's almost all
brand new, unreleased stuff, and he's adamant about it NOT being recorded,
so don't expect to find this in the archives down the road.  To hear this
guy in action you've got to actually BE THERE. Which is what you were going
to do anyway, right? ;)

Oh, and it's still FREE until 11pm!

So... enough pussyfootin' around.

Let's do this!

____________________________

Saturday, May 5th

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant house
every first Saturday at the Endup


featuring from Montreal:

STEPHEN BEAUPR=C9  - Live PA
(Musique Risqu=E9e . Mutek_Rec . ~scape . Force Inc.)

As DJ, producer, MUTEK veteran, and half of the Crackhaus project (alongsid=
e
Deadbeat), Stephen Beaupr=E9 has been an integral member of Montreal's vibr=
ant
electronic music scene for over a decade. His sound splices together the
best of funky cut-up house and bumping minimal techno with a playful, sharp
wit that has delighted both chin-strokers and dancefloors worldwide.


and from New York City:

AMBIVALENT -  Live PA
(M-nus . Clink . Klikhaus . Leftroom . Esparanza)

Kevin McHugh (aka Ambivalent) is a rapidly rising star in the world of
neu-techno and the latest addition to the Minus family of artists.  His
dark, sleazy, and intense musical stylings, epitomized by his current hit "=
R
U OK", make this SF debut a must-see for fans of Troy Pierce, Heartthrob,
and the heavier Minus sound.


plus special guest:

GUTHRIE MILLER  ( tweekin' records . integral concepts )


and resident DJs:

NIKOLA BAYTALA   ( robsoul . junior boys own . s.w.a.t. )
SAMMY D   ( classic . dirtybird . utensil )
CRAIG KUNA   ( concept sf . esdjco )
ALLAND BYALLO   ( liebe detail . floppy funk . mo's ferry )

________________________________________________

The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

_________________________________________________


STEPHEN BEAUPR=C9

Based out of Montreal, Stephen Beaupr=E9 has been involved in the electroni=
c
music scene for more than a decade. Cutting his teeth as an adolescent
promoter for electronic music events in Ottawa, Stephen became quickly
seduced by the more substantial rhythms and textures of house and techno
that was striving to be deeper, funkier and more engaging. He began DJing a=
t
18, always with a mind for the dancefloor, always trying to stay close to
the crowd. With a love for gritty, punchy music at once technological and
organic, Stephen skillfully mixes dancefloor rocking tracks, always trying
to create an atmosphere of humor, excitement and malaise.

As a Producer, Stephen Beaupr=E9 creates much more diverse musical
compositions of disected house/tech. With more emphasis on narrative and
multiple changes in direction, the blend of nervous rhythms and dominant
basslines drive forward melodies created from quirky sources linked togethe=
r
by idyosyncratic threads that sometimes touch very deep. His first solo 12
inch "Dirty Lipreading" came out in 2004 on Musique Risqu=E9e, followed in
2006 by the "Macro-house EP" on ~scape and his first solo full length album=
,
"Foe Destroyer" released on both Musique Risqu=E9e (LP) and Mutek_Rec (CD).
He has (alone and with Crackhaus production partner Deadbeat) produced
remixes for Perlon, Force Inc., and Kalimari, and his works have been
featured in several compliations and mixes, including Akufen's "Fabric 17".

Over the past several years, Stephen has toured in four continents, both
solo and with Scott Monteith as "Crackhaus", dropping down in such cities a=
s
Tokyo, Berlin, Beijing, Detroit, Valparaiso, Mexico City, Paris and New Yor=
k
to name a few, and playing alongside such luminaries as Matthew Herbert,
Richie Hawtin, Ricardo Villalobos, Pole, Isol=E9e and many other like-minde=
d
artists.  This will be his first performance ever in San Francisco!


Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Stephen%20Beaupr%C3%A9

Stephen on MySpace: (with music)
http://www.myspace.com/stephenbeaupre

Music reviews on ForcedExposure.com
http://www.forcedexposure.com/artists/beaupre.stephen.html


________________________________________________


AMBIVALENT

Kevin McHugh (aka Ambivalent) is a native of Washington, DC and resident of
New York City. His musical development began in DC where he was influenced
by the broad nature of that city's music scene. Early exposure to acid-hous=
e
and industrial side-by-side with DC's homegrown go-go and hardcore punk
scenes deeply influenced his music.

After a brief period in London, Kevin moved to New York in 1996. He began
producing a music series inside the Brooklyn Bridge Anchorage for Creative
Time. Over the next 5 years he produced events with artists such as Thomas
Brinkmann, Dimbiman, Carl Craig, Ryoji Ikeda, Pole, and many more. It was
during this time that he began making a connection with M-nus. He went on t=
o
produce events in New York featuring friends such as Magda, Troy Pierce and
his roommate Jesse Siminski (Heartthrob) as well as Matthew Dear, Akufen an=
d
Sammy Dee.

He moved to Berlin in 2004 to help Richie Hawtin produce the Plastikman liv=
e
concert. He later returned to New York and re-dedicated himself to producin=
g
music inspired by his friends. He answered an ad for an apartment, and move=
d
in with a DJ named Camea. She later created Clink Recordings. He DJs
regularly in New York, and on his internet radio show, The Nerd Tank, with
Camea. He has releases and remixes (past and forthcoming) on M-nus, Clink,
Klickhaus, Esperanza, and Leftroom.

The near future is looking very bright for Ambivalent. In addition to being
invited to play live at this year's MUTEK Festival, Kevin has just released
his debut 12" on M-nus entitled "R U OK", the title track of which has
already been selected for inclusion on the upcoming Best of Minus
compilation "Nothing Much", to be released June 1st.


Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Ambivalent

Ambivalent on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/iamambivalent

Music samples + a review of R U OK:
http://www.soulseduction.com/common/item_detail.php?ItemID=3D171456

R U OK teaser video by M-nus:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DoJr6ohRB-h4

Recent interview with Ambivalent on Rhythmism.com:
http://www.rhythmism.com/features/?id=3D246


________________________________________________


GUTHRIE MILLER

Guthrie has been the main music buyer at Tweekin' Records for years, playin=
g
a heavy behind-the-scenes role as musical tastemaker in the Bay. Prior to
that he was the man behind Integral Concepts, an SF monthly techno staple i=
n
the millenial era that featured atists such as Frankie Bones, Hyperactive,
and Andrei Morant.  His extensive collection of classics, coupled with his
access to the freshest new tracks, make this appearance sure to be an early
morning treat.


Tweekin' Website:
http://www.tweekin.com

Guthrie on Myspace:
http://profile.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=3Duser.viewprofile&friendid=
=3D18538705


________________________________________________

http://www.kontrolsf.com

Scott Carrelli
(SatelliteSF, Qoöl, satellitesf.com)

James Zabiela and Nic Fanciulli first struck up a friendship during gigs in 
Asia in 2005. Their mutual understanding of each other’s music coupled with 
the fact they had fun and got into all sorts of mischief together made them 
inseparable. Throughout 2006 the pair experimented playing back2back, 
including New Year’s Day in Nic’s hometown of Maidstone, the sunnier climes 
of Miami’s WMC at Cafeteria and We Love… Space, Ibiza. All received rave 
reviews (no pun intended) and it was proof indeed JZ and Nic needed to take 
this idea further – and so ‘One plus One’ is born.

The concept will encompass a world tour, starting at Miami’s WMC 2007 with a 
One plus One launch party; the USA leg will see the pair touring like rock 
stars as they get aboard a tour bus and gig their way around the country 
covering the length and breadth of America with up to five gigs a week. 
Following this is a month touring the UK’s hotspots, a month in Asia and 
Australia trailed by a full 3 months in Europe centred around Ibiza’s summer 
season. James and Nic will play back2back together on every show. It’ll be a 
multiple CD deck and laptop extravaganza of layering music, bending sounds 
and twisting beats to one mind-blowing effect. With gig offers pouring in 
from every country on planet Earth and nine Festivals already confirmed 
expect more to follow.

In addition to this the duo has struck a deal with Ministry of Sound 
Recordings for a unique One plus One album. A studio mix that will be 
representative of the shows, it will include several bespoke productions by 
James and Nic including a collaboration between the two, personal re-edits 
and all the usual effects and daring mixing people have grown to love them 
for. A spring release, the album will coincide with the tour.

SCOTT CARRELLI BIOGRAPHY:
Famous as an international melting pot and nightlife mecca, San Francisco's 
club scene has produced some uniquely prominent sounds, a situation 
well-exploited by DJ/Producer Scott Carrelli. Often billed as progressive 
house, Carrelli's "contrastflow" sound utilizes progressive, deep house, 
breaks, electro and techno, melding human energy into an emotional dance 
floor journey.

Carrelli attributes his success to his mentor and occasional tag-team 
partner, Spesh, of the successful production team Jondi & Spesh. It was 
Spesh's recognition of Scott's unique style that landed him his residency at 
Qoöl, a world famous "clubbing at happy hour" spot and San Francisco's 
longest running weekly. It was through Jondi & Spesh's record label, Looq, 
where Scott met and began producing with David Gropper of RND . Their track, 
"Wabi Sabi" will be out on Nutbass Records at the 2005 Winter Music 
Conference. A regular guest of Spundae (in San Francisco/Los Angeles), Club 
1015, Opel Productions, and Mezzanine.

One + One: Nic Fanciulli and James Zabiela Info

One + One Myspace

Cover: $15

Advance tickets at: TicketWeb



Marc(O)
The Mario Bros.//OtherWorld//Ill Behavior//The MidnightSons (DC/SF)
www.themidnightsons.com
www.myspace.com/the_mario_bros
www.myspace.com/illectrofunk


5/5/07: TBA/UNDERGROUND (SF)
5/19/07: Ignition @ The Capitol Garage (Sac) w/ Simply Jeff
7/7/07: TBA/UNDERGROUND (SF)
9/1/07: Annual Island Party (Central PA)

------=_Part_63415_24560459.1178413954366
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Well, really I was just making a rhetorical defense for the desire to uphold
the law.  Which was in response to the improper accusation that all people
who support deportation are bigots.  It's a valid viewpoint to think that
laws should be enforced.  That was also entirely separate from my expression
of my own views, and I never specifically endorsed that viewpoint.  I can
explain an idea without agreeing with it.

Rhetorical convention aside, I think that the law needs to be redone, and
until it is an actual just enforcement of the current law is very
difficult.  Most immigrants, I have little problem with their staying.  Some
immigrants behave in an unjustifiable way, and I wouldn't mind their
removal.  Opening the country to unregulated immigration, I believe, would
be a bad idea.  Allowing exploitation of labor is, I believe, wrong and
should be addressed as well.  It's an amazingly complex issue that I hope
will eventually be resolved.

> >> I'm sad to announce that my darling little shop afterglow was robbed
> >> early this morning, sometime between 12:00 (I looked at my shop while
> >> going home last night) and this morning at about 6:00, when my
> >> neighbor arrived at his dental lab & heard the alarm. The thieves
> >> hacked thru the thick wood door to get to the deadbolt, which they
> >> pried apart enough to kick the door in.
> >> The thieves made off with a huge amount of clothing. They didn't
> >> touch
> >> the jewelry or accessories, tee shirts, or a rack with my newest
> >> pieces, Donna Lou's new pants, or Camilla's bicycle dresses. They
> >> targeted the big rack that included the main bulk of my designs and
> >> the collections of these designers, over 150 pieces in all &
> >> totalling
> >> over $12,500 in retail value:
> >> Donna Lou (except for the sailor pants), Nicacelly, and Super Sugar
> >> Ray Ray, and the one remaining tunic by Porcelynne.
> >> For you ladies, don't worry: your pieces are covered by my insurance,
> >> and you will all be taken care of.
> >> My landlord immediately installed a metal sleeve around the door
> >> where
> >> the locks are, and will install yet another deadbolt & possibly a
> >> roll-down door, so I don't expect this to happen again.
> >> If you could look out for anyone trying to sell my designs or the
> >> other designs, who you don't know, or can pass this email along to
> >> anyone who may hear or see anything, I'd really appreciate it. All
> >> items have sewn labels (mine is AC, the others are as mentioned
> >> above)
> >> and are tagged.
> >> This is a tough blow to my little business, but I'm even tougher, so
> >> you can bet I'll be back in full force before too long, & I'm doing
> >> all I can to recover the lost afterglow collection.
> >> Yours, Amy

----- Original Message ----
From: Andrew Phelan <mailinglists@djandrewphelan.com>
To: we dont wanna grow up <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Tuesday, May 8, 2007 12:20:22 AM
Subject: [sfraves] I finally did a new mix and stuff just in time for summer


It's been like 3 years since I put down a proper DJ mix to give out but hey
hey I finally got my shit together with a little prodding.  If you like your
house of the summertime variety, with lots of happy vocals and
disco-liciousness, then this mix is for you.  All tracks were picked out by
everyone's favorite Little Etoile and then assembled by me, which means this
one's for da ladiesssssssssssssssssss:

http://www.djandrewphelan.com/music/Andrew_Phelan_LittleEtoileHouse.mp3

Don't forget to sing along n smile!

And for good measure, here are all my old mixes dating back to 1999:

http://www.djandrewphelan.com/music/Andrew_Phelan_and_Origami_MixedProductio
nSampler1.mp3
http://www.djandrewphelan.com/music/Andrew_Phelan_Thumpin.mp3
http://www.djandrewphelan.com/music/Andrew_Phelan_and_RFM_LiveatSticky2.mp3
http://www.djandrewphelan.com/music/Andrew_Phelan_SweetHome.mp3
http://www.djandrewphelan.com/music/Andrew_Phelan_1984.mp3
http://www.djandrewphelan.com/music/Andrew_Phelan_DiscoStu2.mp3
http://www.djandrewphelan.com/music/Andrew_Phelan_DiscoStu_BSide.mp3
http://www.djandrewphelan.com/music/Andrew_Phelan_DiscoStu_ASide.mp3

And since I'm promoing myself so hard already, here's links to my record
label group and DJ site for me and Origami and The Fingermonsters related
fun:

http://www.prismatictracks.com
http://www.djandrewphelan.com

A

--

mix it up tonight with an organic house base. Tossing
in a pinch of yummy acid tinged with a funky electro
marinade. Topping it off with breaks pieces and techno
bits to spice up the stew...

Grab yourself a side of greens and join us.

Subject: [sfraves] i'm back home now..thanks to all the warm warm wishes, messages and and the hospital visits

I'm finally home..
thou i still feel like i should still be be in the care of the nurses :(

thanks for all the flowers, warm wishes & messages & hospital visits..

after my second surgery..i still feel a bit ickee...the next surgery will be scheduled in a couple a months to fix what was broken...so here is the story of what was broken..

my first surgery was just a routine outpatient laparoscopy to check my cysts in my ovaries and my uterus for endemetriosis..(that checked out cleaned) anywho.... somehow during that surgery they manage to damage my intestine and after being home a few days i started to feel the pain really bad....at first i associated the pain with the surgery then it was it went beyond pain it what bloody hell...

so keith rushed me to the emergency room were they ran tests the most painfull of them all was this ckg rectal thingee..omg...i fucken screamed tears...
*tears up*

so my bloody sunday gets spend on tests tests test..i get admitted...YAY!! i guess..

monday...i'm in surgery again...keith gets a call from one of the surgeons: " she gets to wear a bag"

i don't find it funny..as he does...but he says he hey at least your alive..
yeah yeah..so yeah..they had to do a colostomy on me...

and let me tell you this sucks assssss...

i hate it...

thou it's only for 5 months,,,ONLY 5 long months...
then surgery again...

so you may not see me out at all...

why..

i can't seem to be able to deal with it..and thats the honest truth...

but i should be online not as much..but i'll be around...

so if you want to talk..call me...email me...text me...have lunch or something let me know...

as for now..i won't be doing late nights as my body needs to heal big time..

love you guys..
xoxo
adriana

Subject: Re: [sfraves] LAPD fires rubber bullets into immigration protest crowd

I lost a bunch of coworkers during the door to door "sig heil, your
papers are not in order" raids. Sucked, they were some of the coolest
latin people there. The legals are all tools. ;)

Then again, when you break the law you take a chance. Sell your friend
a couple hits of ecstasy and you PROBABLY won't go to jail, but good
luck if your friend happens to get pulled over and decides to roll
over to avoid a court date.

That said, fuck the police coming straight from the underground. ...
and that said, I hope the LAPD keeps opening fire on innocents so that
eventually all faith in the police collapses and we get some riots
goin. :)


On 5/6/07, Matthew Johnson <prayformojo524@gmail.com> wrote:
> Well, really I was just making a rhetorical defense for the desire to uphold
> the law.  Which was in response to the improper accusation that all people
> who support deportation are bigots.  It's a valid viewpoint to think that
> laws should be enforced.  That was also entirely separate from my expression
> of my own views, and I never specifically endorsed that viewpoint.  I can
> explain an idea without agreeing with it.
>
> Rhetorical convention aside, I think that the law needs to be redone, and
> until it is an actual just enforcement of the current law is very
> difficult.  Most immigrants, I have little problem with their staying.  Some
> immigrants behave in an unjustifiable way, and I wouldn't mind their
> removal.  Opening the country to unregulated immigration, I believe, would
> be a bad idea.  Allowing exploitation of labor is, I believe, wrong and
> should be addressed as well.  It's an amazingly complex issue that I hope
> will eventually be resolved.
>
> On 5/5/07, J.C. <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu> wrote:
> >
> > On 3 May 2007, Matthew Johnson wrote:
> >
> > > Did I say anything different than what you said in your first
> > paragraph?  I
> > > didn't blame immigrants for wanting to come (because there is money
> > here),
> > > and I also denounced unfair exploitation of workers.  Arresting everyone
> > who
> > > employs them isn't the answer, but I also never claimed that blanket
> > > deportation is good either.
> >
> > You actually said that since they're breaking the law, they should be
> > arrested.  That view applies equally to the people hiring illegals as it
> > does to the illegals.  Can't has it two different ways.
> >
> >
> >
> > --
> > http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Bassdrop w/ Lawgiverz, Eskmo - Thursday - FREE!

Evil Breaks presents:

Bassdrop
Thursday, May 10th, 2007
@ Shine (1337 Mission)
930pm - 2am
FREE!!!!


We're back once again for another night of Bass, and this time we're
bringin out the
big guns. Last months show was absolutely great, so we're hopin to see the same
heads out this time plus a few more bright shiny faces.


LAWGIVERZ
(Trigger - UK)
Lawgiverz are the combined talent of Paul R Kidz & Nick Noize. The duo
have been working together for a number of years and were formerly
signed to Mechanoise Records. Between them they have worked with many
of the music and entertainment industries biggest names including the
likes of Dave Stewart of the Eurythmics, Jarvis Cocker and The Human
League! They have also worked with many of the UK's leading breakbeat
artists and labels including Freq Nasty, Wayward Soul, Fuel Records
and Botchit & Scarper. Heavily influenced by Kraftwerk their sound has
been described by Freq Nasty as "Orbital meets Aphex Twin meets
Depeche Mode!" Lawgiverz have also appeared live at some of the worlds
leading breakbeat events. Their live show incorporates multiple decks,
CDJ's and a laptop and the pair mix, scratch and basically remix every
track they drop!

ESKMO - Live!!
(Vertical Sound/Cyberfunk/Mechanoise/Downbeat)

Syd Gris
(Opel Productions/Opulent Temple)

Aaron Jae
(Evil Breaks/XM Radio/SpaceCowboys

Bam
(Evil Breaks/Invibe)


more info: www.EvilBreaks.com

-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.getbammed.com

>same
>heads out this time plus a few more bright shiny faces.
>
>
>LAWGIVERZ
>(Trigger - UK)
>Lawgiverz are the combined talent of Paul R Kidz & Nick Noize. The duo
>have been working together for a number of years and were formerly
>signed to Mechanoise Records. Between them they have worked with many
>of the music and entertainment industries biggest names including the
>likes of Dave Stewart of the Eurythmics, Jarvis Cocker and The Human
>League! They have also worked with many of the UK's leading breakbeat
>artists and labels including Freq Nasty, Wayward Soul, Fuel Records
>and Botchit & Scarper. Heavily influenced by Kraftwerk their sound has
>been described by Freq Nasty as "Orbital meets Aphex Twin meets
>Depeche Mode!" Lawgiverz have also appeared live at some of the worlds
>leading breakbeat events. Their live show incorporates multiple decks,
>CDJ's and a laptop and the pair mix, scratch and basically remix every
>track they drop!
>
>ESKMO - Live!!
>(Vertical Sound/Cyberfunk/Mechanoise/Downbeat)
>
>Syd Gris
>(Opel Productions/Opulent Temple)
>
>Aaron Jae
>(Evil Breaks/XM Radio/SpaceCowboys
>
>Bam
>(Evil Breaks/Invibe)
>
>
>more info: www.EvilBreaks.com

French bus drivers are some of the funniest in the world, almost all  
of them seem to take a wrong turn and end up having to turn the bus  
around, at least this was my experience.  Anyway drove around the  
countryside today and wouldn't be surprised if I end up here again.

inside joke.  Anyone play that game?  It only works on windows.  Or  
evwour.  Please correct me on the spelling.

--

I know that to paint the sea really well, you need to look at it every  
hour of every day in the same place so that you can understand its way  
in that particular spot and that is why I am working on the same  
motifs over and over again, four or six times even.


- Claude Monet

earlier this year, passed away suddenly.  Fortunately we have been able to
dodge all the drama & Hell the the neighborhood organizations have been
causing to have the fair another year.  I've been informed recently that  
we will have to keep fighting though to keep Pablo's dream alive to pass
this 30 year tradition down to generations of Peace Loving People!!!!

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: 5/19/07 : Ignition @ The Garage (Sac) w/ Simply Jeff, Mario B


>StrategiK Events present: IGNITION @ The Capitol Garage (Sacramento, CA)
>
>Your headliner for the evening:
>
>Simply Jeff
>Dj Culture/Phonomental Music / www.simplyjeff.com / XM Radio
>
>Jeff is a 3rd generation Japanese California native who started playing 
>records at an early age for High School dances to private events in the 
>80s. Anything from cuttng edge Electro dance beats, early Hip Hop, New 
>Wave/Gothic to Top 40 dance music was the main formula of his musical 
>strength. Jeff's early versatility to dance music lead him to perform in 
>local nightclubs and radio mix shows. After graduating from The University 
>of Sound Arts for video sweetening and music production. Jeff attended 
>extention courses at UCLA for music business and marketing. During this 
>time Jeff was also interning at Capital Records, Cema Distribution and at 
>the World Famous KROQ FM in Burbank, California. At KROQ, Jeff (known as 
>Spinn at the time) was able to use his production knowledge and made 
>special mega-mixes for artist such as Depeche Mode, Pet Shop Boys, EMF, 
>Jesus Jones to Erasure. After KROQ, it was MARS FM in 1991 that spawn Jeff 
>on the FM air waves as regular on-air personality. MARS FM (based in Santa 
>Monica, California) was the first 24/7 Electronic Dance Station in the 
>Nation. Jeff known as DJ Spinn, hit the FM air-waves every Saturday 
>afternoon with Swedish Eagle on the Mars FM Top 30 Countdown Mix Show. At 
>this time, Jeff also released his first recorded works on vinyl out of the 
>trunk of his car to promote himself as an artist and DJ. Sometime 
>after....Jeff signed his first record deal and started touring across 
>Mother Earth.
>Today the name SIMPLY JEFF is known across the globe for supporting the 
>music he loves the most by being on top of his tour schedule, working at 
>his record shop "DJ CULTURE" in Huntington Beach, his Pod-cast / streaming 
>radio show appropriately called..."THE MIX SHOW ON DJCULTURE DOT COM" with 
>the funny, slurry and sometimes witty co-hosts... Bryan Mizota and Rich (we 
>like to call him "Shure, Shure"). Jeff also finds time to support his music 
>productions by running the Phonomental Music label based out of Newport 
>Beach, California
>
>with special guests:
>
>The Mario Bros.
>
>Daniella Downs aka dj Steve French
>Essential Breaks West / TechFunk Alliance / Mario Bros, SF
>&
>Marc(O) aka The Green Bastard (from parts unknown)
>The MidnightSons / OtherWorld / Mario Bros, SF
>
>What can we say about these guys? They're fucking awesome! The Mario Bros. 
>is made up of one part "daniella downs", one part "Marc(O)" and a whole lot 
>of pimp juice. They are best served straight up in a highball glass...

  =09

  =09
I would like to thank all the patrons, promoters, DJs, artists, and =20
employees of Club Six for an amazing six and a half years. We have =20
owned and operated Club Six trouble free for all these years: there =20
have been no ODs, no stabbings, no shootings, and no underage =20
drinking. Now we have summoned by the Entertainment Commission of San =20=

Francisco for a hearing to suspend our Place of Entertainment Permit =20
and our After Hours Permit. This would mean no DJs, no performers, =20
and no dancing for one month. This would put us out of business.

The complaint states that Club Six violated the noise ordinance =20
anywhere from three to nine decibels above our limitations. Over the =20
last few years we have invested over $200,000 in soundproofing. We =20
continue to do more sound work to improve our situation. Regardless =20
of the outcome of the hearing, I am committed to meeting the =20
guidelines the city has set forth. I have 20 years left on my lease =20
at Club Six and intend to continue to bring quality entertainment to =20
the community and to the City of San Francisco.

My goal when I bought Club Six was to unite all types of people, =20
music, and cultures together in a place where everyone from all walks =20=

of life would be treated equally. It was to create one of the city=92s =20=

top venues in what was and considered to be one of the city=92s most =20
blighted and destroyed neighborhoods: Sixth Street. Do you remember =20
Sixth Street six and half years ago? Friends and business associates =20
told me it couldn=92t be done.

Now, Club Six is the largest minority-owned business and employer on =20
Sixth Street. People from all over the Bay, the country, and the =20
world stop off there. Club Six is the anchor of Sixth Street and in =20
many ways the glue that keeps it together. It has been instrumental =20
in helping to bring more businesses to the neighborhood, and I am =20
very proud to say that I can see my vision of successful co-existence =20=

between all types of people being fulfilled every day. Club Six is =20
Sixth Street!

Our hearing is scheduled to be held in Room 406 of City Hall on June =20
5thand will begin between 4:00 and 5:00 pm. Please show your support =20
for us by showing up and saying a word in our behalf. For now, we =20
will continue to do business as usual. Please come down, listen to =20
some incredible music, dance, and enjoy Club Six. We are open! Please =20=

forward this to a friend, send us an email of support at =20
clubsix@comcast.net , and cc the community leaders below.

Thank you again for allowing me this wonderful opportunity to own and =20=

operate Club Six.


Angel Cruz
Owner, Club Six

Club Six: clubsix@comcast.net
Chris Daly: chris.daly@sfgov.org
Bob Davis: bob.davis@sfgov.org
Mayor Gavin Newsom: gavin.newsom@sfgov.org
SOMPAC: mban@sompac.com
SPUR: info@spur.org
Urban Solutions: info@urbansolutionssf.org


--Apple-Mail-1-878592850--

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: room for rent in raver household 

Hello friends... So perhaps you'll remember that I posted to SFR not too 
long ago regarding finding housing for me and Sean.  We totally lucked 
out and scored a really cool live/work loft in downtown Alameda, which 
we are so excited about!  We have one extra room and are looking to rent 
it out, so I thought I would put the word out to my fellow ravers.  The 
space is pretty sweet, very open, and will be good for small parties 
(which, amazingly, the landlord encourages!).  There's a full kitchen, 
big bathroom, roof access, and cool neighbors. The landlord said we can 
do anything we want with the place, so there are lots of possibilities.  
For more info see our craigslist post: 


http://sfbay.craigslist.org/eby/roo/329503056.html


Love Chelsea


P.S.  We'll be having a housewarming party sometime next month to break 
in our new space, more info to come....

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Tonal - Groovin' Gold this Friday w/ Jay Tripwire!

Friday, May 18th 
10 PM 'til very late
Rock It Science, Prismatic Tracks, and sfhousemusic.com present

Tonal: Groovin' Gold

SF Location: call 888-482-9281 or 415-412-0406, or visit prismatictracks.com
or sfhousemusic.com the day of for directions 
$5 before 10:30, $10 before midnight, $15 after
Free mix CD for dressing in Groovin' Gold (at door person's discretion--make
some serious effort people!)

Big thanks to everyone who made it out to "Pimpin' Purple!"  Definitely one
of the funnest vibes ever, and the outfits were so Pimpy!  Everybody's
asking what's next?  Get ready for the next throwdown in this series of sick
new color themed parties brought to you by some of the hottest crews in the
underground house scene--Tonal: Groovin' Gold! Tonal parties continue
showcase talent flown in from out of town as well as some of your favorite
local house jocks. We look forward to bringing you high quality events, so
strap on your dancing shoes, bring everybody you know and get ready to move
it! 
 
DJ's:

Jay Tripwire (Nordic Trax, Lost My Dog, Jah Love, Vancouver)
feat. Sen - Sei live on keys!

Gemini Soul CD Release Tour!

Ballasts of the West Coast house sound, Jay Tripwire and Sen - Sei will be
teaming up for an exclusive dj set/live performance for us!  Jay's
impressive discography includes releases on such acclaimed labels as
Nightshift, Utensil, Amfibius, Connected, and many more.  It has been way
too long since Jay has graced SF's decks with his dj skills, so we jumped at
the chance to bring him aboard while his new album on Nordic Trax is hot off
the press.  Live on the keys, Sen - Sei is every bit as incredible as he is
in the studio pumping out the hits.  Bringing a dynamic presence and energy
to every set, Sen - Sei is a true crowd pleaser.  These two will most
definitely have you begging for more! 

With Supporting talent:

Andrew Phelan & Origami (Drop Music, Prismatic, So Sound)

Eric Sharp (Rock It Science, Minx)

Ivan Ruiz (Mindless Reality) vs. Jimmy B. (RxFx)

Rob Crush (Crush Collective) 

See you on the dancefloor!

--

Checked by AVG Free Edition.
Version: 7.5.446 / Virus Database: 269.4.0/762 - Release Date: 4/15/2007
4:22 PM

>teaming up for an exclusive dj set/live performance for us!  Jay's
>impressive discography includes releases on such acclaimed labels as
>Nightshift, Utensil, Amfibius, Connected, and many more.  It has been way
>too long since Jay has graced SF's decks with his dj skills, so we jumped 
>at
>the chance to bring him aboard while his new album on Nordic Trax is hot 
>off
>the press.  Live on the keys, Sen - Sei is every bit as incredible as he is
>in the studio pumping out the hits.  Bringing a dynamic presence and energy
>to every set, Sen - Sei is a true crowd pleaser.  These two will most
>definitely have you begging for more!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: MJ Overdose

I don't believe its really possible to OD on marijuana.  You'd have to smok=
e literally thousands of joints to do it, even with today's more potent str=
ains.=0A=0AAlcohol is much more dangerous than marijuana with toxicity leve=
ls around 10+ drinks depending on your body weight etc.  Its relatively eas=
y to drink enough to get alcohol poisoning and it happens all the time.  I =
am sure some on the list can attest to this.  =0A=0AIn contrast its nearly =
impossible to smoke enough weed (without special equipment at least) to app=
roach the toxicity levels reported in the literature.  You are probably mor=
e likely to suffocate trying to do this than you are to actually succeed in=
 poisoning yourself with the weed.=0A=0AWater is actually more dangerous in=
 easily consumable quantities than marijuana.  =0A=0AAmazing and true.=0A=

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: MJ Overdose

 I once shared a tray of pot brownies with a friend of mine and got so
high i thought i was going to die. it took a couple of hours for it
all to hit me, but i seriously melted down. edibles tend to throw me
over the edge, so i could imagine how a noob would feel if they ate an
entire pot brownie of mediocre potency.

a neighbor of mine gave me a toka-cola one day and i gave it to my
boyfriend because he was into edibles. he drank the whole thing while
driving to his mom's house in salinas and literally had to pull over &
let his brother drive because he was freaking out. he couldnt even
smoke pot for weeks after that, and it took him a while to ease back
into it. turns out the toka cola was rated at "x10" which is the
strongest thing the clubs make, according to my neighbor. more for
cancer patients than stoners.

anyhoo, you would need to be a total dweeb to have the nerve to call
911 if you smoke/eat too much weed, but then again i have done
stupider things in life while under the influence.

t

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: MJ Overdose

Remember the term "overdose" refers to a toxic reaction to a consumed chemi=
cal.  Various other negative effects are possible well before you reach an =
overdose level.=0A=0ASmoking, eating, or drinking enough MJ that you feel b=
ad or even like you might die is obviously possible.  But even if you think=
 you are going to die after eating a tray of pot brownies you almost certai=
nly won't.  Not even close.=0A=0AThe toxicity levels for marijuana are lite=
rally thousands of times what people typically consume in contrast to alcoh=
ol where it is only about ten times a typical consumption amount.  You'd pr=
obably need to drink dozens of bottles of that "Toka Cola" stuff to approac=
h a toxic level in your blood stream, maybe more, I'd need to check the act=
ual levels in one of those.  In contrast, you can approach toxic alcohol le=
vels with 3-4 very strong drinks.=0A=0ADriving under the influence can be d=
angerous however.  Don't bake and drive kids.=0A=0APeace,=0A=0APeter=0A=0A-=

  yeah I was scared man!
I have never been THAT high before.
It was the night before my birthday and I had a huge day ahead of me.
So I ate a krispie treat a friend gave me about 11 or 12 that night and 
wanted to be in bed by 2am.
She said only eat half, I ate whole. It was sooooooo good. and I already had 
the munchies from smoking earlier. LoL

welllll 3am comes around and im like curled up in a ball hoping my heart 
doesn't explode and my brain doesn't bleed out my eyes!
my eyes have NEVER been that red.

Also I have never even used visine in my life! I would have friends who 
always use it. I bet they go blind by the age of 40.
lol.
I finally fell asleep around 6am.

Subject: [sfraves] Filter.SF.1.2 preview - Listen to live sets by Mikael Stavostrand + [A]pendics.Shuffle

Not making the treck to DEMF or MUTEK?

Preview these two live sets from our featured artists for
Filter.SF.1.2 May 26 and be proud to say techno is alive and kicking
in the Bay Area over Memorial Day weekend.


Mikael Stavostrand (Sunset Diskos, Berlin, Stockholm):

http://sunset-diskos.com/mixes/Mikael_Stavostrand_Live_Harry_Klein_21
-4-2007.mp3

Kenneth James Gibson aka Apendics.Shuffle (Adjuct, Los Angeles):

www.adjunct-audio.com/KJG/apendics.shuffle_LA_djset_2007.mp3



:: F I L T E R . S F . 1 . 2 ::
Sat. May 26 :: 10 PM till Dawn

Featuring three live sets by:

someone else (foundsound/unfoundsound/philly)

+ [a]pendics.shuffle (adjunct, los angeles)
+ mikael stavostrand (sunset diskos, berlin/stockholm)

also featuring:

PsyBooty's David Justin

Kontakt (Montreal, BABD)
Solekandi (San Francisco, BABD)
Saya (Tokyo, BABD)

Location: Fat City
314 11th St at Folsom
San Francisco, CA 94103

Cost: $10 before 11 with RSVP to Filter2@babd.org
$15 without RSVP before 11
$20 after

More information:

www.myspace.com/filtersf
babd.org



-- 
filter.sf.all night techno monthlies
every last saturday
fat city, san francisco
www.myspace.com/filtersf

>StrategiK Events present: IGNITION @ The Capitol Garage (Sacramento, CA)

>Your headliner for the evening:

>Simply Jeff
>Dj Culture/Phonomental Music / www.simplyjeff.com / XM Radio

>Jeff is a 3rd generation Japanese California native who started playing 
>records at an early age for High School dances to private events in the 
>80s. Anything from cuttng edge Electro dance beats, early Hip Hop, New 
>Wave/Gothic to Top 40 dance music was the main formula of his musical 
>strength. Jeff's early versatility to dance music lead him to perform in 
>local nightclubs and radio mix shows. After graduating from The University 
>of Sound Arts for video sweetening and music production. Jeff attended 
>extention courses at UCLA for music business and marketing. During this 
>time Jeff was also interning at Capital Records, Cema Distribution and at 
>the World Famous KROQ FM in Burbank, California. At KROQ, Jeff (known as 
>Spinn at the time) was able to use his production knowledge and made 
>special mega-mixes for artist such as Depeche Mode, Pet Shop Boys, EMF, 
>Jesus Jones to Erasure. After KROQ, it was MARS FM in 1991 that spawn Jeff 
>on the FM air waves as regular on-air personality. MARS FM (based in Santa 
>Monica, California) was the first 24/7 Electronic Dance Station in the 
>Nation. Jeff known as DJ Spinn, hit the FM air-waves every Saturday 
>afternoon with Swedish Eagle on the Mars FM Top 30 Countdown Mix Show. At 
>this time, Jeff also released his first recorded works on vinyl out of the 
>trunk of his car to promote himself as an artist and DJ. Sometime 
>after....Jeff signed his first record deal and started touring across 
>Mother Earth.
>Today the name SIMPLY JEFF is known across the globe for supporting the 
>music he loves the most by being on top of his tour schedule, working at 
>his record shop "DJ CULTURE" in Huntington Beach, his Pod-cast / streaming 
>radio show appropriately called..."THE MIX SHOW ON DJCULTURE DOT COM" with 
>the funny, slurry and sometimes witty co-hosts... Bryan Mizota and Rich (we 
>like to call him "Shure, Shure"). Jeff also finds time to support his music 
>productions by running the Phonomental Music label based out of Newport 
>Beach, California

>The Mario Bros.

>Essential Breaks West / TechFunk Alliance / Mario Bros, SF

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

Date: Thu, 17 May 2007 16:28:18 -0700
From: Gavin Varitech <gavin@djvaritech.net>
User-Agent: Thunderbird 1.5.0.10 (Windows/20070221)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To:  sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <141592.68047.qm@web57412.mail.re1.yahoo.com>
In-Reply-To: <141592.68047.qm@web57412.mail.re1.yahoo.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Progressive music..

Progressive is certainly not new. What Skills told is about is 
progressive trance (cheesy clubber's trance), which is a whole world 
away (in my mind) from what most people I know of refer to as 
"progressive" - deejays like Sasha, Dubfire, or John Digweed. You could 
put Paul Van Dyk in that category too from time to time if you want - 
which is really just progressive house (which is not really all that 
progressive if you ask me). Worlds apart.

Chris wrote:
> I read the rave faq and they were talking about a new style of a electronica called progressive..  Im interested in checking it out and giving it a chance.. Does anyone on the list know about the genre or have any insite into this style of music? I called skills dj workshop and they said the first place to start is to look up djs like Tiesto, Armin Van Burren, and Paul Van Dyk.. What kind of parties play this kind of style..
>        
> ---------------------------------
> Be a better Heartthrob. Get better relationship answers from someone who knows.
> Yahoo! Answers - Check it out.

Gavin Varitech <gavin@djvaritech.net> wrote:  Progressive is certainly not new. What Skills told is about is 
progressive trance (cheesy clubber's trance), which is a whole world 
away (in my mind) from what most people I know of refer to as 
"progressive" - deejays like Sasha, Dubfire, or John Digweed. You could 
put Paul Van Dyk in that category too from time to time if you want - 
which is really just progressive house (which is not really all that 
progressive if you ask me). Worlds apart.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Progressive music..

IMO Jondi and Spesh's Qool party used to be "the" progressive house party in SF, although I think they've gone beyond the progressive house thing now.  I couldn't name another equally well known event focused on progressive that's still going.

Haven't been to Qool in several years at least however.  I don't go out on Wednesdays very often these days.  This party has been going down every Wednesday night at 111 Minna for close to a decade now.  

Check:http://www.qoolsf.com and http://looq.com

But start here: http://www.qoolsf.com/define_qool/

Good people, good times.  Or so it was back in the day...

Peace,

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: Gavin Varitech <gavin@djvaritech.net>

Sent: Thursday, May 17, 2007 7:03:36 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Progressive music..


Sasha, Dubfire, and Digweed all play at Ruby Skye in the bay area 
exclusively I think. But you don't have to check them out, they're just 
the big names. There are plenty of places to hear dope prog in the city. 
People on here will be able to tell you better than I can though...

> Whats the difference between prog trance and prog house? Where do djs like sasha, dubfire, and digweed spin at?

> progressive trance (cheesy clubber's trance), which is a whole world

Subject: [sfraves] Apollo Update

Hi All,

I saw that Amber asked about Apollo earlier today, but I
accidentally deleted my messages.

Just got off the phone with Apollo's partner, Joey.  Apollo's
still in the hospital - it's been a month, today.  He's doing
about the same -which is good- but it's not great.

To all outside appearances, he's not really cognisant, but the
doctor says there's brain activity.  He's still battling his
fever, and the doctors are working diligently to find out the
cause.

Joey's reading all of your e-mails to Apollo - he's also
keeping them in a scrapbook for when Apollo gets better.  You
can send messages to Apollo via Joey at:  eagleqr@speakeasy.org

I'm visiting Apollo on Saturday - I'll try and send an update
afterward.  Keep sending your healing vibes his way.

>Burren, and Paul Van Dyk.. What kind of parties play this kind of style..

From: "Sean G" <rationalhatter@gmail.com>

Subject: [sfraves] re: Berlin

To those that asked: it's fucking sick. I'm tempted to immediately
expatriate here. I don't know what the actual political-social climate
is, but I have never felt simultaneously this free AND safe in any
city on earth. Haven't seen too much of western Berlin, but the
atmosphere in the east is... amazing. All I can say.
Friedrichshain(sp) is poor and covered and filth and graffiti, but I
never get that paranoid itch between my shoulderblades that I get in
even the calmest downtown SF neighborhoods.

I dunno about techno, though. Maybe the whole thing will be over soon?
I've been hearing more american pop-hiphop in dive bars in
restaurants, and '80s-funk-reggae with a little electro' seems to
dominate a lot of the little clubs.

Cassiopeia is going to be investigated tonight ... supposedly some
good breaks and tech house? Watergate was clubby and the techno
reminds me of what san francisco did to house music. booooring.
Berghain wouldn't let us in the door because we were obviously not
homosexual enough. Dont I get unofficial homo points from being in
SF??? I thought my wrists were getting a little limp, but obviously
not limp enough...

more information upon my return,

sean

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
