Message-ID: <993310.17892.qm@web50011.mail.re2.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] BSP - "People's Voice" - 06.08.07

Astral Productions and Sound of Mind Present... 

People’s Voice
A Journey Through Psychedelic Music – Friday, June 8th

People's voice is the first in a series of events designed to
give you the chance to make your voice heard and suggest
artists and DJ's you would like to hear play in SF.  The
ultimate goal is to bring new and fresh talent into the scene,
and create a musical journey throughout the night.

A core group of four DJ's have teamed up together to bring this
concept to life, but it relies on you to give us your input.
This is essentially your event, so come out and let your voice
be heard.

More info on how to give us your suggestions will be available
at the event.

Your entertainment for the evening is:

Goldilox (Sleevin Records, www.djgoldilox.com)
Goldilox has been playing underground parties for years, and is
no stranger to the San Francisco electronic music scene.  She
started out dropping crack house on vinyl, and now she has come
a full 360 degrees and will be doing a fully digital mix.  Her
set is not to be missed.

Kepi (Sound of Mind, kepiandkat.com, desertdwellers.org)
Kepi has been opening for psytrance acts for years in SF, and
keeps his tracks selections unique -  not scared of genres, he
spins everything from downtempo to breaks to psytrance.  Thump
Radio resident and a favorite when spinning outdoor desert
gatherings including Moontribe gatherings outside of LA,
Burning Man, and events in and around the West Coast and
abroad.

Tandava (CCC)
>From Goa to Greece, and from Portugal to London, Tandava has
traveled the globe to seek out the freshest psytrance sounds to
bring back to S.F. Well known by many local heads, he has
thrilled the dance floors at Burning Man and underground
parties for many years with his own style of stomping melodic
morning sets.  Recently he and Sentient brought us Shane Gobi
from Nano records at the outdoor “ReAwaken” gathering, and a
wicked good time was had by all.  Boom!

Atum (Astral Productions)
Atum has been DJing psychedelic trance for over a decade. He
has played alongside some of the best trance artists from
around the world, and with his smooth mixing style has been
known to rock the dance floor.

Sentient (Vaporvent Records)
Sentient has been blasting dancefloors with his groovy and
infectious psytrance sound since 2001.  From Thump Radio
resident to co-founder of the Synchronize weekly, from Burning
Man to Brazil, his track selection and mixing skills cause
crowds to explode.


Ambient Mafia Chillout Room:

Based out of San Francisco, The Ambient Mafia has been
redefining chillroom culture since late 1999. Specializing in
all things chill, The Mafia can be found hosting chillrooms at
multiple-room club venues, massive warehouse events, one-offs,
and underground events.

Downtempo, dub, midtempo, bossa nova, atmospheric drum n bass,
IDM, underground hip hop, ambient: the Ambient Mafia DJs run
the whole gamut of chill-out genres.  Times may change, but the
Mafia mission remains the same – to give people music that
makes them think, dance, and above all...chill.  More info can
be found about the Ambient Mafia at www.ambientmafia.com

The Ambient Mafia crew will be in full force with:
Actual Rafiq
Olde Nasty
Peek
The Captain
Redstickman
Seventh Swami
Squelchy
We Are Not Pandas

Visuals by the one and only Doctor Spook!
Backdrops by Dreamtime

Limited Capacity // $14 presale // $20 at the door
FOR PRESALE TICKETS CLICK HERE (or cut and paste the following
link)
http://www.groovetickets.com/ordersystem/Groove/eventviewqb.asp?AffilID=93&EventsID=30569&PGname=Sound+of+Mind

Fully Loaded EAW Sound System
@ The Gingerbread House - Connecticut and Cesar Chavez, SF

18 and up
10 pm to sunrise

-----------------------------------------------------
 www.redstickman.com

 new downtempo mix online, you should check it out.
-----------------------------------------------------

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)

Well it's been a while, been kind of busy.  But I got a chance to see  
Spidey 3 this weekend, I must say I think it was very good and fit  
quite well with the other 2 ... I went to see the movie at the  
Cinnamon at the corner of Taikos and Staddivinenky.  These kids saw me  
rolling a cigarette and they gave me a thumbs up, asked me where I was  
from, I told them San Francisco, they said they would like to go to  
Las Vegas someday to "see the bitches".  So thumbs up to Lithuania,  
I'll be in Poland tomorrow, then I think Norway and Iceland.  The list  
goes on.  What a way to end my time in the Delta Quadrant.  Sweet as a  
*bitch*, yo!

--

Well someone steals half a loaf of bread, or three quarters a loaf of
bread from you, what are you going to do, thank them for not stealing
the whole loaf?  Thank you thank you, massa ...

- Ed Rosenthal

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Rave culture..

History?

Some would say rave culture is extinct, some would say it is in the process of being reborn, and some would even say it never really existed in the first place.  you make the call.

Welcome Chris.  

Start here: http://www.livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm and here: http://music.hyperreal.org/library/machine_soul.html and also here: http://www.fantazia.org.uk/Scene/timeline.htm

and see also:
http://www.thesite.org/drinkanddrugs/drugculture/drugstrade/thehistoryofrave
http://www.csp.org/nicholas/raveTOC.html
http://www.ishkur.com/culture/
http://innerrave.org/meditation.html

Peace,

Peter

above-ground venue. Hit me up for discount list privvies.

============================================================

Filter.SF - Techno All Night at SoMA's Fat City
Memorial Day Weekend
Saturday May 26, 2007
9:30 PM till dawn

This month for Memorial Day weekend, Filter returns to Fat City with
two of the biggest names who have helped shape America's new techno
sound: Someone Else (Foundsound/Philly) and Apendics.Shuffle
(Adjunct/LA).

Names like these don't play together in the U.S. very often, and
Someone Else is soon set to expatriate to Berlin, so don't miss a rare
opportunity to experience them together with Sweden's Mikael
Stavostrand, founder of Mitek and Sunset Diskos labels.

Live PA by: Someone Else (Foundsound, Philadelphia)
[A]pendics.Shuffle (Adjunct, L.A.)
Mikael Stavostrand (Sunset Diskos, Stockholm/Berlin)

Plus special guest: David Justin (PsyBooty Records, San Francisco)

Filter residents:

Saya (Filter, Tokyo)
Solekandi (Filter, San Francisco)
Kontakt (Filter, Montrael, San Francisco)

RSVP for $10 before 11 to Filter2@babd.org
$10 all night for Beta members
$15 before 11 w/out RSVP
$20 after 11

Fat City
314 11th Street at Folsom, S.F.
With enhanced sound and visuals, chill mezzanine and after-hours beverages

Looking ahead, June 30th's Filter will feature one of top tech house
acts from Sweden - Joel Mull (Inside Records), plus Beretta Grey's
Seth Troxler, oneof the rising stars of Detroit's  new techno sound.

Pics of last month's filter party + sample sounds here: myspace.com/filtersf

filter.sf.all night techno monthlies
every last saturday
fat city, san francisco
www.myspace.com/filtersf

History?

Some would say rave culture is extinct, some would say it is in the process of being reborn, and some would even say it never really existed in the first place.  you make the call.

Welcome Chris.  

Start here: http://www.livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm and here: http://music.hyperreal.org/library/machine_soul.html and also here: http://www.fantazia.org.uk/Scene/timeline.htm

and see also:

be disco, there will always be 80's, there will always be hiphop,  and yes, 
there will always be ravers.

-troy

It is my hypothesis that the fundamental source of conflict in this  
new world will not be primarily ideological or primarily economic. The  
great divisions among humankind and the dominating source of conflict  
will be cultural. Nation-states will remain the most powerful actors  
in world affairs, but the principal conflicts of global politics will  
occur between nations and groups of different civilizations. The clash  
of civilizations will dominate global politics. The fault lines  
between civilizations will be the battle lines of the future.

- Samuel P. Huntington

Subject: [sfraves] BioRhythm this Sunday 5/21, Free day Party GG Park

Taken from the acid totem email list:

It's about that time of the month again!  Most of you should have have
Monday off, so what's your excuse to skip out on BioRhythm this month?
Good-  didn't think you had one!  Now, what incentive do we have to end this
party at sunset?  Hmmm, well, we don't really have one!  We'll be playing
music well past sunset, maybe even until 10pm- we'll see how long the park
rangers will tolerate us before pulling the plug!  Bring all the usual:
friends, bbq's, refreshments/drinks, frisbees, footballs, hoolahoops and
moonbounce shoes.  Most of all, bring yo freaky self!   Now for the line up,
drum roll please!

Homero Espinosa  aka dj Huey  (Yerba Buena Discos / Detour Recordings)
Phokus  (Korpus Kallosum)
Unityvybe  (Acid Totem / Biorhythm)
Ben Haus  (Acid Totem / Biorhythm)
Kris Kent  (Acid Totem / Biorhythm)
Flook   (Acid Totem / Biorhythm / Purgatory Cruiser / Yellow No. 5 )
Evolution CQ

Noon til 10pm????
5000 watts of Bass powered by M1 Audio
Burgers, Hotdogs and Chicken for sale at Rob Dogg's BBQ Bazaar    negotiate
your price!

Directions:  Bunny Meadow, located behind the Conservatory of Flowers on
Conservatory Drive West.  Find parking around Funston and 4th Ave.  There is
a paved bike path located almost directly across from 4th Ave on the Golden
Gate Park side of Funston.  The path is less than a two minute walk to bunny
meadow!  For those of you who need visual guidance, click the link for a
map:  http://www.acidtotem.net/images/bunnymap.jpg


***Please pack out or throw away/recycle all of your trash!  Extra trash
bags will be on site.  There is no smoking in the park, if you are going to
do it, please keep it out of site and throw your butts away in a garbage
can!**

------=_Part_171555_15925218.1179962752685--

Daaaaaamn!!! Is Aaron flying back to play @ Mighty on Sunday?

Evil Breaks <info@evilbreaks.com> wrote: WOW!!!!!!!! There's a bunch of AMAZING stuff going on this weekend.  

On top of Evil Breaks doin another Day Party @ Mighty with Kraddy, Alxndr, Donna Matrix, Kuze, and the EB boys, Aaron Jae is also playing at Dax & Raindance's "Slide into Summer 6" on Friday, and an event called "Slipmat Science" in Bend, OR on Saturday.  

To make matters even worse Aaron's newest mix, "Crunky", is being featured on the super fabulous www.BijouBreaks.com website for your listening and downloading pleasure. Please visit the site if you'd like to check it out.  This is goin to be an INSANE weekend baby!!!!!!


Info on all these wonderful events is down below......



[2007-05-25]

Dax & Raindance Present: 
Slide into Summer 6

Rainance is joining forces once again with Slide to celebrate and elevate the vibe and the onset of summer. We will be going off to make an already cool venue with an underground vibe even cooler and decked out in a virtual aquatic wonderland.

Folks this is going to be a party, not just another night in club landia 

We will also be raffling off a pair of tickets for the Raindance Campout as well, a $250 value - 5$ raffle tickets the profit form this will be donated to baby hazel http://babyhazel.org/Hazel 

the winning ticket to be posted at the coat-check @ 2am 

DJ's for the night include: JUSTIN LONG, GODDESS ALCHEMY PROJECT (Live!), LANCE DESARDI, MANCUB, AUDIOVOID, LITTLE JOHN, MOZAIC, WORTHY, AARON JAE, SAMO, DFUNKT, and ELIAS. Visuals by: DAX, VJ SCIENCE, and LUX LUCIDUS, with Live painting by Spencer. 

Located @ Mighty (119 Utah st), 9pm to 5am, $5 before 11pm, $15 after, Gemini Birthdays get in 2 for 1 after 11pm.



[2007-05-26]

Slipmat Science - Bend, OR 
Aaron Jae willl be playing Bend, OR with Rogue Element, Trona, Dig-Dug and others.  If you're in the area, please check the event out.  The following links are for the flyers if you're interested.

Front: http://i25.photobucket.com/albums/c73/ells210/wrekagnize-front-web.jpg
Back: http://i25.photobucket.com/albums/c73/ells210/wrekagnize-back-web.jpg



[2007-05-28]

Evil Breaks Memorial Day Party & BBQ
@ Mighty (119 Utah st.)
3pm - 9pm
FREE!!!!

We had such a wicked amazing time at Mighty last month that we couldn't pass up on the chance to do it again. We will once again be doing it at Mighty with a couple of grills outside, free hotdogs, and some amazing beats. So if you want anything special grilled up, please bring it with you and we'll toss it on the grill.

You bring the meat, we got the beats.


Kraddy (Glitch Mob/Refiner)
Rodman (Crazy Ass Alien)
Donna Matrix (Newzbreaks)
Alxndr (Downlow)
Kuze (Nitewise)
M.O.D. (Evil Breaks) - hiphop/oldskool breaks set
Bam vs. Aaron Jae (Evil Breaks)

more info: www.EvilBreaks.com





Important Dates:

May 25th - Slide into Summer 6 @ Mighty - SF, 21+
May 26th - Rogue Element, Trona, Aaron Jae - Bend, OR
May 28th - Evil Breaks: Memorial Day party & BBQ @ Mighty 3-9 - SF, 21+
Jun 1st - Get Freaky w/Rogue Element & Space Cowboys - SF, 21+
Jun 10th - Aaron Jae @ 2nd Sundays w/Doc Martin & Donald Glaude@ KMR - SF, 21+
Jun 14th - Bassdrop with Stabilizer FREE @ Shine - SF, 21+
Jun 16th - Funrazor presents: Kid Kenobi underground 11-7 - SF, 21+
Jun 21st - Opel event with Elite Force, Syd Gris, Aaron Jae - SF, 21+
Jul 3rd - Dyn-O-Might - Evil Breaks/Sister SF/In Deep - SF, 21+

Subject: [sfraves] [BSP] Sat ALL NIGHT @ Fat City :: [a]pendics.shuffle, someone else, stavostrand, psybooty

Filter 1.2 - Memorial Day Weekend All Nighter at Fat City.

Minimal Techno, Tribal, Electro-Tech-House, Experimental and...PsyBooty

Saturday, May 26, 2007 - Sunday, May 27, 2007
9:30 PM till Dawn
Location: Fat City
314 11th Street at Folsom

$10 RSVP to filter2@babd.org

More Info: myspace.com/filtersf

Filter, a new all night monthly at Fat City, is just the ticket for
scratching that itch for the deeper grooves pointing the way to the
future. This party's solid monthly lineup features the biggest names
driving new techno-inspired sounds on dancefloors world-wide.

Filter features 3 Live PA performances by:

Someone Else (Foundsound, Philadelphia)
[A]pendics.Shuffle (Adjunct, L.A.)
Mikael Stavostrand (Sunset Diskos, Berlin)

Check out recent interviews and downloads on the Modifyer blog:

modyfier-modifying.blogspot.com/

With special guest: David Justin (PsyBooty Records, San Francisco)

And Filter residents:

Saya (Filter, Tokyo)
Solekandi (Filter, San Francisco)
Kontakt (Filter, Montrael, San Francisco)

About the artists:

Someone Else aka Sean O'Neal (Foundsound, Philadelphia) =96 Live PA

Voted as one of the best live electronica acts of 2006 by Groove
magazine, Someone Else has been a major force in forwarding
minimal/experimental dance music since 1998 with label projects Tuning
Spork and Foundsound, Unfoundsound moving a once-obscure sub-genre of
house music onto the world's dance music stage.

Someone Else's San Francisco performance will feature material from
his new album "Pen Caps and Colored Pencils" (cd/2x12") on Foundsound
Records.

Kenneth James Gibson aka [a]pendics.shuffle (Adjunct, Los Angeles) =96 Live=
 PA

Since the late 1990's Kenneth James Gibson has produced countless
releases under multiple monikers, including Eight Frozen Modules,
[a]pendics.shuffle, KJ Gibbs and dubLoner. Since December alone,
Mr.Gibson has produced nine new releases for Adjunct, Orac, Mo's Ferry
and Lessizmore that firmly establish this LA producer as one of most
prolific names in minimal dance music production.

Mikael Stavostrand (Mitek, Sunset Diskos, Berlin) =96 Live PA

Born in Stockholm and now based in Berlin, Mikael Stavostrand is
considered key feature of the Swedish electronic music scene for his
unique interpretations of minimal club techno as well as his
experimental electronic music productions.

Stavostrand has played Mutek in Canada, plus Mexico, Japan and
throughout Europe. His collaborations have included the Luus project
together with Johan Fotmeijer, the Bulgur Brothers, Johan Skugge and
Andreas Tilliander. More recently, with Kenneth James  Gibson, aka
[a]pendics.shuffle.

David Justin - DJ

A&R and co-founder of PsyBooty Records, David Justin is the ear behind
the PsyBooty sound. His music fuses a solid percussion base and funky
rhythmic swing with precision sound design and a penchant for
intellectually stimulating musical and atmospheric structures.

Cost:
$20
$15 before 11 w/out RSVP
$10 before 11 w/ RSVP

Next month's Filter:

June 30th - Joel Mull (Insider Records, Railyard Recordings/Stockholm)
+ Seth Troxler (Beretta Music/Detroit)


--=20
filter.sf.all night techno monthlies
every last saturday
fat city, san francisco
www.myspace.com/filtersf

Regardless of the accuracy of the claims being made in this forward (which,
after reading the directive itself, aren't accurate at all):

Ron Paul would be a truly excellent presidential candidate.  He's the only
person who has portrayed himself well in Republican debates, and
unfortunately all the Democrat front-runners are just "controversial"
because of race or gender and don't back any meritorious policy other than a
very generalized, wishy-washy "end the war (but don't ask us how)."  A
strict constitutionalist is exactly what our country needs, if you ask me.

The problem is not the candidates, but the system itself.  It's been
troubled for quite some times, and the worsening process has been vastly
expediated since GW took office.  Almost all of our politicians buy into the
status quo of the current system on both sides of the aisle.  It's about
damn time we had a politician who doesn't flip flop on issues because of
pressure from their party, the media, or the people; and truly stand for
what they believe is to be the best interest of the American PEOPLE.

Any updates on Ron Paul in the major news media?  I haven't heard much since
the last debate, but I think CNN has a debate coming up... tomorrow???

Rudy Giuliani was a partner in a law firm.  That law firm represented
many clients.  One of those clients was News Corp.  That doesn't mean
that Giuliani had any personal involvement or influence over said
firm's interaction with Fox.  Indeed, the article you pointed us
towards seems, on the whole, pretty _critical_ of Giuliani.

Hey, remember when this list used to be about RAVES&STUFF?  That was
hella coo...

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Candy kids

I actually kind of miss when there was more crossover between the  
candy/plur and the mature/SFRaves sides of the scenes; both on the  
list and in real life.  It seemed like the intermingling kept things  
a little more vibrant, fresh, and interesting.

But there WERE days when you'd find candy kids (albeit usually not  
wearing much candy) at the SFRP, Vibration, Moksha, and so on,  
parties; and when you'd see the likes of Osby, Nicola, Alida,....  
even Ryan and Lydia... at a HAPPY KIDS party!  (Don't bother denying  
it.  I have pictures.)

I miss those days.  Now, if you go to one kind of party, that's their  
clique and you pretty much won't see those people at another kind of  
party.


cya,
john

Don't know if you saw this; I'm copying it from the Evil Breaks list. Their last BBQ was a f'n great time!


>>>[2007-05-28]

Evil Breaks Memorial Day Party & BBQ
@ Mighty (119 Utah st.)
3pm - 9pm
FREE!!!!

We had such a wicked amazing time at Mighty last month that we couldn't 
pass up on the chance to do it again. We will once again be doing it at 
Mighty with a couple of grills outside, free hotdogs, and some amazing 
beats. So if you want anything special grilled up, please bring it with 
you and we'll toss it on the grill.

You bring the meat, we got the beats.


Kraddy (Glitch Mob/Refiner)
Rodman (Crazy Ass Alien)
Donna Matrix (Newzbreaks)
Alxndr (Downlow)
Kuze (Nitewise)
M.O.D. (Evil Breaks) - hiphop/oldskool breaks set
Bam vs. Aaron Jae (Evil Breaks)

more info: www.EvilBreaks.com
>>>

Rgds,

CKG

Chris <giftofgab86@yahoo.com> wrote:    Naw i used to wear candy to parties but i stoped going. I was wondering if people still wear candy to parties? I used to listen to happy hardcore and a little hard trance but know im older and i like the more progressive sound. I remember someone saying that drug dealers wore candy to let people know they had drugs. i wasnt really sure if that was true. ive met a lot of candy kids that didnt sell. i wanted to know the true origin before i go callin myself a candy kid or what ever. i just wore it back then cause it looked nice. now the whole happy hardcore thing sounds cheesy. I like artists like ltj bukem paul van dyk anything on om record label mark farina and what not. It seems to me like with the whole idea of wearing candy there are a lot of things that are going to be assumed about you. My folks make real jewlery for business and i wanted to do the same thing just not for sell. i wanted to know to all the candy kids what do your
 breacelets mean to you? For me its hard to even make them since im picky. i dont see myself wearing more then one at a time, if even one. I really wanted ideas on who to make nice ones.

Richie and Magda are playing the next night at Avalon Hollywood with 
(who is IMO the best techno DJ on the planet) Marco Carola! I'm having a 
hard time deciding if I want to drive to the city for the Kontrol 2 year 
with Zip & Baby Ford or hop on a plane Saturday night, head down to LA, 
hear Marco play live on the West Coast, and fly back home in the 
morning. I wish somehow they could have gotten Marco up here with Richie 
the next night. As far as deejay skills go he's on a while different 
level than Richie and Magda combined.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Any cool day parties going on this weekend?

Memorial Day Party & BBQ
Monday, May 28th, 2007
@ Mighty (119 Utah st.)
3pm - 9pm
FREE!!!!

We had such a wicked amazing time at Mighty last month that we
couldn't pass up on the chance to do it again. We will once again be
doing it at Mighty with a couple of grills outside, free hotdogs, and
some amazing beats. So if you want anything special grilled up, please
bring it with you and we'll toss it on the grill.

You bring the meat, we got the beats.


Kraddy (Glitch Mob/Refiner)
Rodman (Crazy Ass Alien)
Donna Matrix (Newzbreaks)
Alxndr (Downlow)
Kuze (Nitewise)
M.O.D. (Evil Breaks) - hiphop/oldskool breaks set
Bam vs. Aaron Jae (Evil Breaks)


Timeslots:

3-415 aaron jae & bam
415-5 kuze
5-545 donna matrix
545-630 alxndr
630-715 mod
715-815 kraddy
815-9 Rodman

Chris <giftofgab86@yahoo.com> wrote:
    Naw i used to wear candy to parties but i stoped going. I was wondering if people still wear candy to parties? I used to listen to happy hardcore and a little hard trance but know im older and i like the more progressive sound. I remember someone saying that drug dealers wore candy to let people know they had drugs. i wasnt really sure if that was true. ive met a lot of candy kids that didnt sell. i wanted to know the true origin before i go callin myself a candy kid or what ever. i just wore it back then cause it looked nice. now the whole happy hardcore thing sounds cheesy. I like artists like ltj bukem paul van dyk anything on om record label mark farina and what not. It seems to me like with the whole idea of wearing candy there are a lot of things that are going to be assumed about you. My folks make real jewlery for business and i wanted to do the same thing just not for sell. i wanted to know to all the candy kids what do your breacelets mean to you? For me its
 hard to even make them since im picky. i dont see myself wearing more then one at a time, if even one. I really wanted ideas on who to make nice ones.

Dear Will,

As comprehensive as the below may be, it seems that you may have left 
the wit and wisdom of Ishkur, our generation's Artemus Ward, out of the 
mix.

For example:

http://www.ishkur.com/captions/index.php?num=25
and http://www.ishkur.com/pixe/

tho', for some unknown reason, Lyndzie, Ishkur's go 2 grrrl for all 
things candy, went all goth, and shit, around mid-September about 6 
years ago.

Go figure.

"Talking to your candykids
> We asked our crisis counselors for tips on talking to your candy kids 
> about the attack on Ishkur. Their tips follow in the points below.
>
>     * Tell candykids the truth. "Candykids can handle anything as long 
> as they're high on ecstasy," says SpArKlE_FaIrY, a local candykid 
> psychologist.
>     * Ask your candykid what they're imagining and feeling. Tell them 
> their thoughts, feelings and behavior are totally fucked up.
>     * Let your candykid know that it's OK to feel bad vibes, and let 
> them know that you may feel bad vibes too, but that you will keep them 
> away from the evil jib.
>     * Reassure your candykid that he or she is cute. Tell them Ishkur 
> and his men are working very hard to make people laugh. Let them know 
> that despite the fact that there are some fucking stupid people out 
> there, many more are fucking stupid enough to laugh at.
>     * If your candykid asks if something like this could happen to 
> them, like say they have a really fucking generic candy name and some 
> other kid on the other side of the continent has the same name and 
> starts bothering your candykid, pressuring them to change it, let them 
> know nobody has the right to do that, and to tell the other kid 
> they're a fucking crackhead.
>     * Do not let your candykid visit Ishkur.com all the time. 
> Encourage them to do drugs or go to a rave. Watch for warning signs 
> that your candykid may need professional help. Warning signs include 
> listening to the radio, watching tv, reading the paper, or some other 
> senseless, boring crap like that."

Will Penna wrote:
> I was at many of those parties some 15 years or so ago. Of course, 
> there ARE these sites:
> http://www.candykids.net/

Subject: [sfraves] Hardcore DJ....

So this may or may not be funny to you but it was to
me...

"me and my friend are hardcore dj's trying to come up,
and we would love to play...blah blah blah...."

Now, I think I know the answer, but really, there was
a time not so long ago that if someone came up to me
and said, "I', like a totally hardcore DJ..." I would
have assumed that they meant they spent all of their
extra time spinning records.... Like, "i'm a harcore
Biker" or "I'm a hardcore skater" etc....

I'm old. 

Thats rad.

The snooping into your phone bill is just the snout of the pig of a
strange, lucrative link-up between the Administration's Homeland
Security spy network and private companies operating beyond the reach
of the laws meant to protect us from our government ... Worried about
Dick Cheney listening in Sunday on your call to Mom? That ain't
nothing. You should be more concerned that they are linking this info
to your medical records, your bill purchases and your entire personal
profile including, not incidentally, your voting registration.

I think it all depends.  

If the 1/100 so called "signal" postings is really good, I don't mind reviewing the remaining 100 noise posts to find it. Like many of you I've also been setting up filters to ignore some of that noise...

There are parties listed here that just aren't listed on other "rave" sites or lists for good reason.  I'd like to see more of those of course and I'd like to see the rave calendar rejuvenated and updated.  Sfraves may not be dead, but it could be a lot more useful...

But then I work on "low signal to noise" applications for a living, so maybe I've just become used to wading through the muck to find the hidden gems.  I also have five kids so I'm used to high noise environments. ;)

Peace,

Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Choice of music



I think some people on this list have just been partying for a long, long time.
Some of us have heard it all and done it all.  Progressive trance just has
a lot of generic hooks that works well to get a lot of "fresher" party people
going.  Nothing wrong with that, there is a reason Teitso is so huge.  But
a lot of people here on this list demand more innovation in their dance music.
The big builds and the faux emotional melodies just don't cut it for us 
anymore.

-troy

Dude, you have to do this.  

I will consult on wardrobe and hairstyle.

Also, FWIW, here's a page from Paul O's real official superstar DJ handbook:

Jokenfold: "Just when the 'big' break is about to come in your 'big' track put your hands in the air and wave your champagne glass around to get the audience really excited."  

Audience: "Whoo hoo Paul Oakenfold's hairy armpits!  Expensive champagne spilling on the records!  Oh yeah!"

Jokenfold: "Don't do this too often or anyone that is paying attention at all will notice that you aren't really mixing, but rather playing a prerecorded mix CD or MP3."

Peace,

Peter

P.S. Yes I actually observed him do this.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] User profiles?

That profile site was built, then removed when the original author left 
and there was no edit/delete functionality built-in (people complained). I 
looked at the code...these days I understand it and could technically 
modify it...but's it way old code and a bad patchy approach.

Our latest calendar STAR-raves suffered the same demise...was picked up by 
SD-Raves too, then broke and discarded, the Zope platform too difficult to 
maintain from outside volunteers.

We tend to have this web revamp discussion every 6 or months don't we??? 
;-)

I know NYC-Raves, or their moderator (Trout) in particular is working on 
new code (PHP/MySQL), but it's been pretty unsubstantial email exchanges 
thus far. I haven't had much back-up firepower to offer him.

I'm not on that Tribe group, but I know it's not an hyperreal-endorsed 
solution. But given we can't get our collective butt in gear it sounds 
like a viable alternative.

If there are people out there that want to build/improve the SFRaves site 
just let me know. There are lots of contributions that we could use from 
programming apps to just editorial work, and even basic archiving.

by the way...*just* got back from OODE (CF/Oregon campout). Had a rockin' 
time. (sorry, no pics yet)

BUT...the weekend before I did this:
http://www.estioko.com/private/_estioko_wedding_condensed/

:-)

-terry

------------------------------------------
terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org

I *LOVE* techno, but the last two times I saw Richie and last time I saw 
Magda were not deserving of bothering with seeing them again till I hear 
some really good reviews.

DJs need to fucking figure out that Serrato/FS/whatever is NOT all that 
reliable, and sounds like horrific shit when it skips (that was Magda who 
ate it there, her set at the Rickshaw last year was abyssmal at best), and 
they both were dropping snoozers, ferreal.  By immediate comparison, last 
time Jeff Mills played I was too busy dancing to be as wild eyed and 
slackjawed as my brain was telling me to be, just fucking CHOICE TASTY 
TECHNO SOUL GOODNESS.  I think I'm turning into a racist, I honestly 
haven't liked a techno set from a white kid in a long time.  Richie is 
almost the epitome of what I don't like about some techno sets... super 
smooth mixing of records that sound almost identical and lack real quirk 
or soul = boring as hell.

andyw

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy

  The Love Underground <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Message-ID: <479017.13194.qm@web60325.mail.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Too Much happening friday

Weeeeeelllllll...  To put it in perspective, there a lot of things that Live, at least (and maybe Torq, on the straight-up dj software side) can do that even the best vinyl/cd jock can't.   The problem is that many folks simply use these things as an easy way to get past that pesky beatmatching thing and don't use them to their full potential, which is, of course, not an option on decks.

I agree with Andy though, on most of this- there is next to no emotion in a featureless, seamless, robotic set like some of these folks throw down.  That human element, and a little shock-and-awe quick mixing/tricks/etc is what makes techno (and most other mixable music) work.  Otherwise it's like watching a ghetto-tek set where the dj lets each track play for 5 minutes then mixes into the next.  It's just not how these things were meant to be played.

When I play out with a laptop, I do tons of live remixing, looping and composition on the fly, creatively use effects, and often play instruments and do turntablism when I'm not in the middle of mixing tracks together.  I feel that all that extra work injects that human element that some automixed sets lack.

It also looks pretty cool, unlike squinting into a little screen the whole time.

-G

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Too Much happening friday

On 30 May 2007, georgeC | origami wrote:

> Weeeeeelllllll...  To put it in perspective, there a lot of things 
> that Live, at least (and maybe Torq, on the straight-up dj software 
> side) can do that even the best vinyl/cd jock can't.  The problem is 
> that many folks simply use these things as an easy way to get past 
> that pesky beatmatching thing and don't use them to their full 
> potential, which is, of course, not an option on decks.
>
> I agree with Andy though, on most of this- there is next to no emotion 
> in a featureless, seamless, robotic set like some of these folks throw 
> down.  That human element, and a little shock-and-awe quick 
> mixing/tricks/etc is what makes techno (and most other mixable music) 
> work.  Otherwise it's like watching a ghetto-tek set where the dj lets 
> each track play for 5 minutes then mixes into the next.  It's just not 
> how these things were meant to be played.
>
> When I play out with a laptop, I do tons of live remixing, looping and 
> composition on the fly, creatively use effects, and often play 
> instruments and do turntablism when I'm not in the middle of mixing 
> tracks together.  I feel that all that extra work injects that human 
> element that some automixed sets lack.

Then you best come back down to KZSU and demonstrate some of that! :) 
Andy says he's coming down too!

>
> It also looks pretty cool, unlike squinting into a little screen the whole time.
>
> -G
>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] User profiles?

While many on the list have some level of coding skills, I'd actually favor a low tech/no tech solution for the calendar. 

How about a weekly email to the list with a summary of events for the coming week?  We don't need a fancy ZOPE or RoR implmentation of a calendar, we just need to aggreagate the information and share it.  One idea, just have all BSPs also forward to a specific email address which would then be reviewed and editted by list volunteers to create a weekly "calendar" or upcoming events email.  The email should be sent out Tuesday or Wednesday to the whole list so that people have it in time for Thursday parties.

The user profiles are a harder question in some ways I think.  But I don't like migrating to a community platform (i.e. Tribe) that might disappear in a few months or years, or might decide to charge $$$, or might implement monitoring practices we wouldn't agree with. Etc.

Congrats on the wedding!  Looks fabulous...what a beautiful place and what a beautiful wife!  

I liked marriage so much I did it twice!

Peace,

Peter



----- Original Message ----
From: Terry Estioko <terry@hyperreal.org>
To: J.C. <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org; Eric Spire <ericspire@yahoo.com>
Sent: Tuesday, May 29, 2007 11:08:44 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] User profiles?


That profile site was built, then removed when the original author left 
and there was no edit/delete functionality built-in (people complained). I 
looked at the code...these days I understand it and could technically 
modify it...but's it way old code and a bad patchy approach.

Our latest calendar STAR-raves suffered the same demise...was picked up by 
SD-Raves too, then broke and discarded, the Zope platform too difficult to 
maintain from outside volunteers.

We tend to have this web revamp discussion every 6 or months don't we??? 
;-)

I know NYC-Raves, or their moderator (Trout) in particular is working on 
new code (PHP/MySQL), but it's been pretty unsubstantial email exchanges 
thus far. I haven't had much back-up firepower to offer him.

I'm not on that Tribe group, but I know it's not an hyperreal-endorsed 
solution. But given we can't get our collective butt in gear it sounds 
like a viable alternative.

If there are people out there that want to build/improve the SFRaves site 
just let me know. There are lots of contributions that we could use from 
programming apps to just editorial work, and even basic archiving.

by the way...*just* got back from OODE (CF/Oregon campout). Had a rockin' 
time. (sorry, no pics yet)

BUT...the weekend before I did this:
http://www.estioko.com/private/_estioko_wedding_condensed/

:-)

-terry

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Massive or Underground


There are no underground events.  All parties are fully permited and held 
at licenced establishments.  All state and local laws are strictly adhered to.

There is no such thing as a massive.  They do not exist.  You might be 
thinking of a "Rave" and since the passing of the Rave-Act, they do not 
exist either.

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Massive or Underground

Massives are big commercial events, like Coachella.  The more people that exist at an event, the better chance you have of meeting psychos, thugs, or twattish jerks in general- it's just statistics.

UGs are fairy unicorn fluff, from the planet Zalframacissh, twisted around a double helix of pelican DNA.  Because no humans attend, you're not likely to be threatened by one.  However, that also means that you are not in the correct slice of the astral plane to attend one yourself.  

Bummer.

Subject: [sfraves] BSPish - Join me and Dinner Party Records for my release party on Friday.... (tomorrow)

My new record label, Dinner Party Records, is throwing a big party to celebrate my new album coming out, at Fat City in SF tomorrow!  I'll be playing my new rock stuff live, along with my label mates French Miami (one of the funnest bands I've heard in a while) and Master/Slave, a great synthpop/rock duo, and the Dinner Party DJ Crew- Shawn Allen and Van Carr.



We've got art being shown by 7 artists and some innovative video stuff.  You can get a copy of my new record before it even hits stores, too.



Woot.

Info about the event and links to me and all the musicians involved is here: http://www.myspace.com/dinnerpartyrecords



Anyway, see you all on Friday, it is absolutely imperative that you attend.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="0-2140953424-1180638697=:6884"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
Message-ID: <447994.6884.qm@web57408.mail.re1.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Whats it all about?

--0-2140953424-1180638697=:6884
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

For me its all about the music. I wouldnt really call myself a raver. I wouldnt really be all bent on going to every single party someone throws. And I'm not trippin if a party is legal or not. After a while you grow up and realise that most of that stuff really doesnt matter. Well I did. I listen to music that is of good quality and i pick the parties i plan on going to based on the music being played the djs skills and wether I can find the damn thing. Im more toward finding parties that are fully permitted so getting shut down wont be an issue and finding parties that have an address so i can know where the event is so i can have a general idea of where it will be instead of getting lost in some city with a high crime rate. Im just trying to use common sense. It would be nice to go to parties that are in industral areas but them days seem to be over and no one really attends anyway. Life is about evolving you cant stand in one place for the rest of your life. You can but
 things will pass you by. To all you hardcore ravers keep it goin. Im just not one no more.

 
---------------------------------
The fish are biting.
 Get more visitors on your site using Yahoo! Search Marketing.
--0-2140953424-1180638697=:6884--

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Whats it all about?

If you go to mainly "legal" massives , and you are saying you are going 
strictly for good music , I'd say, that's a VERY relative statement.

More often than not I have heard better music at underground events, and 
this is coming from someone who had access to one of the best clubs in the 
country for 5 + years.

You are living in the Bay Area...if you are indeed looking for quality 
events with good music, you have but to attend 3/4's of the events that 
happen on a weekly basis. You ain't in Kansas no more Toto - so try thinking 
outside the box and do something "dangerous".

And FYI - there are parties in"industrial" areas semi-frequently. You just 
need to know where to look for them.

For someone who's supposedly been raving for years though, you sure have a 
narrow and rather awkward view of the "scene" and how it works these days...

Subject: [sfraves] (bsp) [KONTROL] 2-year anniversary with Baby Ford and Zip, Saturday, June 2

Saturday, June 2nd, 2007

[KONTROL]

TWO YEAR ANNIVERSARY!

Two years in, and what better reason to celebrate
than the fact that techno is alive and well in San
Francisco!  On this momentous occasion, we couldn't
be more thrilled to present to you not one, but yes,
TWO of the most legendary figures in modern techno
performing side by side:
 

ZIP  &  BABY FORD
Perlon:Berlin  |  Trelik.Ifach.Perlon.Klang
Elektronik:UK 
 
Zip (aka Dimbiman) is Thomas Franzmann, owner and
co-founder of Germany's trail-blazing minimal house
label
Perlon.  Also 1/2 of Pantytec (with Sammy Dee), Zip's
quirky, crisp, and downright visionary take on modern
dance music has influenced a generation of DJs,
dancers,
and producers alike. 
 
Baby Ford is, quite literally, one of the founders of
the
UK's acid-house scene.  After experiencing mainstream
success as a club music pioneer in the early 90's, he
took an unexpected turn towards more experimental and
minimalistic sounds.  Rather than becoming a footnote
in
dance music history, nearly 20 years later he's still
pushing boundaries; still at the top of his game. 

with resident DJs and special guests:

SAMMY D + DJ WRONG?
CRAIG KUNA + SASHA BRAVERMAN 
ALLAND BYALLO + KELLEY B.
NIKOLA BAYTALA + MILES EGNER
  
________________________________________________

The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

____________________________________________________

Full bios, pics and FREE music:
http://www.kontrolsf.com

[KONTROL] on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf

[ground.KONTROL] on Western Addition Radio:
http://www.westaddradio.com/kontrol/ 

Flyer front:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K24F.jpg
Flyer back:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K24B.jpg 
Poster:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K24P.jpg 

____________________________________________________


ZIP  (aka Dimbiman)
 
(Bio courtesy of residentadvisor.net)
Thomas Franzmann aka Zip aka Dimbiman, co-founder of
the label Perlon, is familiar with the dancefloors
around the world and famous for his tremendous minimal
shifts within the 4/4 scheme. He has an illustrious
musical history which began in 1986 as singer in the
band Second Voice. In 1992 he moved to Frankfurt and
joined the EBM band Bigod 20. After several releases
the band split. In 1996 he got together with Markus
Nikolai and Chris Rehberger to form the audio-visual
project Pile. In 1997 he and Nikolai founded the
Perlon label, on which he has released under the
pseudonyms Dimbiman, Pantytec (with Sammy Dee) and
Narcotic Syntax (with James Dean Brown). In 1999 the
SuPERLONgevity compilation was released, featuring
'Bushes', a track that has since garnered
chart-topping remixes from the likes of Derrick Carter
and Fatboy Slim.  There have since been 3 more
successful label compilations bearing the
SuPERLONgevity name. 
 
Franzmann also records with Peter "Baby" Ford and has
appeared on Ford's label PAL SL. He is a regular guest
DJ in clubs around the world and holds residencies at
Robert Johnson (Offenbach) and his legendary monthly
label showcase, " Get Perlonized" at the Panorama Bar
(Berlin). He also participates in the Narod Niki
project, occasional collective laptop live jams
initiated by Ricardo Villalobos and Richie Hawtin. He
has released tracks and remixes on Perlon, Playhouse,
Force Inc, Novamute and others.  Hot off a performance
with Baby Ford at this year's D.E.M.F., this will be
Zip's first San Francisco appearance in 7 years.  

Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Zip
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Dimbiman
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Pantytec

Perlon website:
http://www.perlon.net

"The Secrets of Superlongevity" by Philip Sherburne:
http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/feature/37459/The_Month_In_The_Month_In_Techno

 
 
_________________________________________________
 

BABY FORD
Baby Ford aka Peter Ford is one of the most
recognizable names in current dancefloor techno and
was one of the founders of the U.K. acid house scene. 
He's released records under a slew of pseudonyms,
including Casino Classix, El Mal, Solcyc and his most
frequent, Baby Ford. His early work -- heavily
influenced by the late-'80s acid house sound, as well
as Chicago producers such as Marshall Jefferson, Ron
Trent, Armando, and Larry Heard -- appeared primarily
through the Rhythm King label, and included classic
cuts such as "Oochy Koochy", "Children of the
Revolution", and "Fetish". 

Material has also appeared on Sire, Source, and
Insumision/Transglobal. He's released four full-length
albums to date, including the debut Fordtrax (a staple
of most techno DJs) and 1997's Headphone Easyrider,
one of his more listener-friendly albums. His recent
work has appeared mostly through Trelik and Ifach, two
of the U.K.'s most highly regarded experimental techno
labels, and both of which Ford has a hand in managing
(Trelik together with Eon's Ian Loveday; Ifach with
Mark Broom). 

He's also collaborating with Thomas Melchior as Soul
Capsule and as Sunpeople they released together the
track "Check Your Buddha". With Ian Loveday he
collaborated on a number of projects (including
Minimal Man), both for Trelik. Less active as a
remixer, Ford has reconfigured tracks for Stefan
Robbers' Florence project and pop techno group
S'Express, among others.


Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Baby%20Ford

The world of Baby Ford:
http://music.hyperreal.org/bford/

Review of "Sacred Machine" + an interview with Baby
Ford:
http://www.themilkfactory.co.uk/music/bford.htm

 
_____________________________________________________
 
http://www.kontrolsf.com

> He's also collaborating with Thomas Melchior as Soul
> Capsule and as Sunpeople they released together the
> track "Check Your Buddha". With Ian Loveday he
> collaborated on a number of projects (including
> Minimal Man), both for Trelik. Less active as a
> remixer, Ford has reconfigured tracks for Stefan
> Robbers' Florence project and pop techno group
> S'Express, among others.
>
>
> Discography:
> http://www.discogs.com/artist/Baby%20Ford
>
> The world of Baby Ford:
> http://music.hyperreal.org/bford/
>
> Review of "Sacred Machine" + an interview with Baby
> Ford:
> http://www.themilkfactory.co.uk/music/bford.htm

From sfraves-return-139253-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu May 31 21:02:31 2007
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-139253-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 21985 invoked by uid 1103); 31 May 2007 21:02:29 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 21966 invoked from network); 31 May 2007 21:02:29 -0000
Date: Thu, 31 May 2007 13:57:49 -0700 (PDT)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: The Love Underground <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <20070530151023.I15228@kzsu.stanford.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.62.0705311208280.5811@atari>
References: <465D2A0C.8050209@dementim.com>  <20070530004528.F17770@kzsu.stanford.edu>
 <5c23c6720705300100o24e28da4n108ce467ef271947@mail.gmail.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.62.0705301348520.7217@atari> <20070530151023.I15228@kzsu.stanford.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Too Much happening friday


I'm actually loving this discussion as JC is one of my favorite people to 
discuss the "decline of DJing" with, and GeorgeC was my band's bassist, 
co-singer/writer and in-house studio wiz for a couple years (and like 
myself, living a double life as a techno/house kinda person with published 
releases, dj & live bookings and all that).

On Wed, 30 May 2007, J.C. wrote:
-&e->On 30 May 2007, AndyW wrote:
-&e->
-&e->> almost the epitome of what I don't like about some techno sets... super
-&e->> smooth mixing of records that sound almost identical and lack real quirk
-&e->> or soul = boring as hell.
-&e->
-&e->And you just dissed all the Traktor/Abelton DJs out there too.

Funny, I just played a live set out of Ableton last weekend.  Can't say 
how "live" or punching it was, but it was a bunch of stuff I wrote ripped 
up into parts so I could fiddle with it right there and then, etc.  
People danced, it was my own shit, I fiddled and swooshed and whatnot in a 
live context.  Probably not as cool as showing up with a 909, 303 and a 
reel to reel tape recorder while rolling my own tampons, but still a live 
performance by my definition.

That said, I'm seeing this weird full circle thing.  I picked up DJing 
over a decade ago because I'd grown to hate how stoic and tired bands had 
become.  Instead of 5 people playing this superrehearsed cruft with 
matching outfits and worked out stage moves and backstage sampling and all 
this, you could just show up with a box of records and be kinda... well... 
punk really.  Play anything in any order, drive the energy of a room, 
twist spacetime, manage tension, neato stuff really.  But I was limited by 
what the records that were sold were so... I started buying gear and 
started playing out live.  Over the years the MPC, rack of synths and 
effects, and all that gave way to the most powerful piece of gear of all, 
the computer.  I can literally make/playback any sound imaginable, my 
power is infinite.  And also, I look like I'm reading my fucking email no 
matter how insane what I'm doing inside the world of virtualized synth, 
software, reaktor, max/msp, ableton, whatever.  Even in the realm of such 
performances like "laptop battles", the method & performance mechanics 
fell away (I remember after getting eliminated in the later rounds of a 
laptop battle a few years back, Gold Chains who had been one of the judges 
asked me how I felt about being kicked by a guy cheerleading over simple 
file playback while I was rocking a custom Max/MSP patch and getting 
bonafide kooky... should you be able to beat the devil in a guitar faceoff 
at the crossroads with a tape recorder?).

Now, I feel like showing up to a empty stage, and belting my frustrations 
into a microphone in my tired slightly out of key voice while breaking 
strings on a guitar plugged into an amp on the verge of failure is the 
real deal.  I drop a pick, it changes, my drummer looks at me like this 
one ain't working as well as it could and we'll finish early.  If we play 
a cover tune, it's still *us* playing it, which twists it into being our 
work anyway.

So yeah, I love DJing, but hate what it's becoming.  I've seen laptop DJs, 
"vinyl driven" laptop playback system (even helped develop one), was an 
early adopter of cds and all that.  In response to some of what you were 
saying, even if you're sweating your ass off the same way you would be if 
you were on bass or behind a drum kit, it often looks like checking an 
EBay auction while playing a mix.  The "this hand motion made that sound" 
effect of seeing a band on more primitive instruments dissolves.  It's 
viable music, no doubt about it, but the show, of rocking two records 
dies, and it's frustrating that in a world of more and more possiblities, 
more and more dj sets/live shows are just boring.

So I ended up with (at least for my own standards) clearly defined roles 
based on the kind of thing I'm doing... it frames the context of what it 
is I am doing:

 * DJing (andyw) = records (exception, I'll play CDs of my own stuff cause 
little of it was put out on vinyl).  Upside, I can be a retard... scratch, 
backspin, all that shibittle.  Cueing and beatmatching are ungogdly fast 
with vinyl, and I've got a couple tons of records so why not, ya know?  
Downside is, I've all but stopped buying records as local shops no longer 
tend to stock new stuff I find interesting, and I was never a big fan of 
online shopping.  Some of the best memories I have are while DJing, 
period.  There's something to be said for how damn fun it is, but those 
parties barely happen anymore.  Not every set can be for 3000 people on 
NYE right after John Selway opening with a test pressing of my first 
overseas release while people are just going apeshit.

 * Live PA (mutor/mutorsoundsystem) = Gear / Laptop playing exclusively my 
own stuff.  I've written a bunch of tunes, tried shopping them to labels, 
some of them sold, some of them didn't, this is me getting a chance to 
play them in a fun kinda way.  And also, showing up to a party with a 
crusty black G3 laptop is retro badass.  It's the most personal statement 
you can make in a way, but... sometimes I wish I could just drop a Steve 
Stoll track in the middle of it all.  But I can't, cause then I'd be like 
all those other people "playing live" but really sorta not playing 
entirely their own stuff, which I think is just false advertising.

 * Band (the lag) = No computers rule - (specifically - laptops + 
sequencing + samplers).  It's hard work, prone to mishaps and brainfarts 
and microphones that feedback and thrown sticks and breaking strings and 
cracking voices... it's also fun as all hell, immediate, hard to fake, 
sweaty primal monkey brain silliness, etc.  People don't wonder if we're 
sampling cause it's a freaking guitar plugged into an amp and a freaking 
drum kit... nothing up my sleeve.

It might be that when sampling became easy and accessible with computers, 
sampling in music had to step up and become more artistic.  The spectacle 
was over.  I think in a similar way, with obiquitous "song selection and 
set order" interfaces like iTunes, Winamp and the iPod, Djing has become 
so democratized now that it's hardly noteworthy.  Rather than seeing it as 
a matter of skill, style, performance and quality... we determine the 
worth of a DJ set by how closely the taste of the DJ matches our own and 
at best hear a couple future favorites.  Tools like Traktor and Ableton 
Live (when used as a DJ tool) eliminate the last technical barrier (that 
pesky parlor trick called beatmatching) and make it possible for anyone to 
DJ in even a dancefloor context.  

Will we see the heavens open up to a new kind of DJ that shreds on 
anything we heard before, or will we see countless shit DJs wearing 
cheeseball playa fashion with poor taste dropping their new mashups and 
recycling genres those who have been in the dance community for more than 
a couple years have already heard rehashed 3-4 times.  Somewhere in all 
this, I've realized sometimes the best thing to do when asked to play a 
set is not to "DJ" as I'd seen it for years as some sort of performance, 
but rather just relax and put on some good music from my iPod, walk away 
from the mixer and get some sun and talk to people.

Performers up, Djs down, I have seen the future of DJs as center stage and 
it's fucking boring.
andyw

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

I wouldnt say I've been apart of the scene for ever but my experiences have been probably different then yours. When I attended underground events the music wasnt all a+. Maybe the ugs you went to had good djs. My way of doing things works for me, it might not work for you. In my eyes a raver is someone who attends raves. Im not trippin if it is a "rave" or not what i was saying is im going where ever the music might be. You say there are parties in industrial areas semi-frequently why dont you send me a private email about that privately so not to step on anybodys toes. I've never been to a massive the most of the parties I went to were maybe a couple hundred. My point in those emails is that im thinkin about giving those massives a chance. I really want to look into the weekly clubs too.

Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:  If you go to mainly "legal" massives , and you are saying you are going 
strictly for good music , I'd say, that's a VERY relative statement.

More often than not I have heard better music at underground events, and 
this is coming from someone who had access to one of the best clubs in the 
country for 5 + years.

You are living in the Bay Area...if you are indeed looking for quality 
events with good music, you have but to attend 3/4's of the events that 
happen on a weekly basis. You ain't in Kansas no more Toto - so try thinking 
outside the box and do something "dangerous".

And FYI - there are parties in"industrial" areas semi-frequently. You just 
need to know where to look for them.

For someone who's supposedly been raving for years though, you sure have a 
narrow and rather awkward view of the "scene" and how it works these days...

Chris <giftofgab86@yahoo.com> wrote:  For me its all about the music. I wouldnt really call myself a raver. I wouldnt really be all bent on going to every single party someone throws. And I'm not trippin if a party is legal or not. After a while you grow up and realise that most of that stuff really doesnt matter. Well I did. I listen to music that is of good quality and i pick the parties i plan on going to based on the music being played the djs skills and wether I can find the damn thing. Im more toward finding parties that are fully permitted so getting shut down wont be an issue and finding parties that have an address so i can know where the event is so i can have a general idea of where it will be instead of getting lost in some city with a high crime rate. Im just trying to use common sense. It would be nice to go to parties that are in industral areas but them days seem to be over and no one really attends anyway. Life is about evolving you cant stand in one place
 for the rest of your life. You can but
things will pass you by. To all you hardcore ravers keep it goin. Im just not one no more.

Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:  If you go to mainly "legal" massives , and you are saying you are going

events with good music, you have but to attend 3/4's of the events that
happen on a weekly basis. You ain't in Kansas no more Toto - so try thinking
outside the box and do something "dangerous".

need to know where to look for them.

For someone who's supposedly been raving for years though, you sure have a
narrow and rather awkward view of the "scene" and how it works these days...

How do you the people on the sfraves list feel about the whole glowstick dancing. For me I really see it as a form of dancing and expressing one self. I know some people associate it with ecstacy and visuals but i see it for more then that. For some its might be hard to dance to these rythms. But with glowsticking its more of a abstract way of dancing to the music.

On Thu, 31 May 2007, Chris wrote:
-&e->How do you the people on the sfraves list feel about the whole 
-&e->glowstick dancing. For me I really see it as a form of dancing and 
-&e->expressing one self. I know some people associate it with ecstacy and 
-&e->visuals but i see it for more then that. For some its might be hard 
-&e->to dance to these rythms. But with glowsticking its more of a 
-&e->abstract way of dancing to the music.

-&e->---------------------------------
-&e->Sick sense of humor? Visit Yahoo! TV's Comedy with an Edge to see what's on, when. 

Never really "got it".  Honestly, had better visuals off a kid wearing an 
adidas track suit under blacklight than that poop.  And also, it's 
disposable plastic cruft that only lasts for a few hours.

I'm also jaded to high hell this week for some reason.

Oh, also, fire dancing is the glo-stick dancing of the paleolithic.

Oh, also, if you put a glostick on a string, and you hit me in the face 
with it, that's assault and I'll flip out.

Oh, also, if it's about expressing yourself, have you considered something 
not everybody else does?  Caipoera, performance art, costumes, getting 
involved with production or promotion, selling drugs, pickpocketing, 
etc... you don't have to express yourself the same way as everybody else.

(note : andyw industries llc does not recommend or condone such disgusting 
criminal activities as picking pockets, selling drugs, or party promotion 
and may have included those for the purpose of getting a slight chuckle 
out of fellow jaded sfraves listers)

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy

fully permited means alot. I went to an "underground"
last weekend that i found out about from the sfhouse
web site and the event reached capacity by midnight -
so they weren't letting anyone else in. i ended up
sneaking in through the back after befriending this
very nice candy girl -

but a underground that closes it's entrances before 12
is kind of weird, the show ended prpmptly at 4:30 so I
was just getting into it by the time it ended.

I think that's when the quality of promoter really
makes or breaks the event.

one thing nice about end up - is that u know it's a
consistant - always an option even after the
underground gets shut down.

"Chris"

You remind me of a guy back in 1999 named ""Honest
Abe." It's hard to take what you write seriously when
in one post you talk about all your party experience
and in the next you ask what a party is. 

I suggest you go to ravelinks.com to find the
"information" and/or "people" you are looking for.

Most people introduce themselves on this list. Most
people know the names of the people they have gone to
massives with in the past. Most people don't wonder
aloud about glow-sticking.

Verbage can be learned or taught... but sometimes,
like when my parents used to try and be cool, and say
rad, they just said it at the wrong time or in the
wrong way. Know what I mean?

E

> > >going to based on the music being played the djs
> skills and wether I can

> > >permitted so getting shut down wont be an issue

> > >have an address so i can know where the event is

> > >idea of where it will be instead of getting lost

> > >crime rate. Im just trying to use common sense.

> > >parties that are in industral areas but them days

> > >one really attends anyway. Life is about evolving

Eric Spire <ericspire@yahoo.com> wrote:  "Chris"

You remind me of a guy back in 1999 named ""Honest
Abe." It's hard to take what you write seriously when
in one post you talk about all your party experience
and in the next you ask what a party is.

"information" and/or "people" you are looking for.

people know the names of the people they have gone to
massives with in the past. Most people don't wonder
aloud about glow-sticking.

like when my parents used to try and be cool, and say
rad, they just said it at the wrong time or in the
wrong way. Know what I mean?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Whats it all about?

Sir, you can understand the paranoia and suspicion based on how much the 
government has shit on people who just wanna gather around and dance to 
techno.

While I understand there were certain elements that needed to be cleaned up, 
the vast majority of us underground kids are in it for the music.  We take 
care of each other and don't cause harm to those around us.

It sounds pretty American of us, to be completely honest.

love always

Richard McCheese

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"

Glowsticking is cool to watch, for about 15sec as you are walking through a 
party but, when is see them dancers that dance around the black lights and or 
dance circles it just makes u want to join in and dance. Which brings up this 
next question? I'm sure u remember in your newbee years that u would go to a 
party just to go, not because the DJ or what he was playing, sure u started to 
make a log on the type of edm and DJ u would prefer checking out but, depending 
in what "state of being" u were in would make u remember what actually u 
liked about the party. did u like the music, sound system, the lighting, the 
props, the visual projections, or were so assed out that u don't remember anything 
which, would mean that u had a good time so, next time this promoter throws 
another party, most likely u will attend. my earlier days were somewhat like 
this but, now being 10years older from that seen, you become much more critical 
about things and people dancing with Glowsticking is an art expression that i 
pretty much have lost interest in.


**************************************
 See 
what's free at http://www.aol.com.

--part1_c5a.11f29a46.3390b9aa_boundary--

I knew it had goen from bad to worse when I was working at a party and saw 
that some people had brought in bicycle "ass lights" strapped to their 
hands.  The friends would take turns sitting on the floor while the one 
with the ass lights would do a little light show in front of their face 
with the blinky lights spinning all over.

Watched one guy start to seize from the lights and enhancements that wern't 
sold at the bar.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] glowsticking

Ok, so I am going to aswer this question as if "chris"
were a nOOb...

Glowsticking is best done by getting the biggest ones
you can at walmart. When you crack them, and the
chemical reaction starts, it is imperative that you do
the following quickly, or the glow affect will
dissipate. Cut open the glow stick, get as much in
your mouth as possible, lubricate your eyes with it
too, and rub whatver is left all over your hands and
face. Now, you are a walking light-show. Run around
the UG you choose to attend alone because you don't
want to miss your ride home even though you have no
license and therefore could not get there or home
yourself. When running around, make sure to keep your
mouth open and wave your hands up in the air like you
just don''t care. When the glow fades, seek medical
attention.

E

> some people associate it with ecstacy and visuals
> but i see it for more then that. For some its might
> be hard to dance to these rythms. But with
> glowsticking its more of a abstract way of dancing
> to the music.

Subject: [sfraves] Cool glowsticking?

The only for-real good glowsticking I have ever seen
was the Redstickman... That was actually pretty dope
back in the day... Black suit with red thin
glowsticks.... From far away, and even pretty close,
the Redstickman would be dancing on stage or around
the boooth, and it actually looked like a redstickman
drawn like a cartoon, or maybe a laser...

High people in e-puddles giving eachother light shows
in between jumping up to scream for the titanic
breakdown = not cool.

E

only cool one i've ever seen was some guy at whistle in NJ who had a string
of long glow sticks(about 5-6 on each one, about 6 feet of material)
actually do some insane hand work with it, then proceeded to bend his body
so that the sticks became a huge circle bending in any direction....lit up
the area he was in, and the place was dark as hell...

then the floor sank and god swallowed me whole.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] User profiles?

We have a website that uses IPB. It runs on PHP/MYSQL and has  
everything that you seem to be looking for (user profiles, calendar,  
automatic email updates). We set it up with the intention of building  
more of an online community around electronic music. We are currently  
providing a space for a few different collectives and could easily  
add an area for SFRaves.

You can see the board at http://www.collectivevibe.org/

Just a thought...
Paul

On May 31, 2007, at 7:06 AM, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> While many on the list have some level of coding skills, I'd  
> actually favor a low tech/no tech solution for the calendar.
>
> How about a weekly email to the list with a summary of events for  
> the coming week?  We don't need a fancy ZOPE or RoR implmentation  
> of a calendar, we just need to aggreagate the information and share  
> it.  One idea, just have all BSPs also forward to a specific email  
> address which would then be reviewed and editted by list volunteers  
> to create a weekly "calendar" or upcoming events email.  The email  
> should be sent out Tuesday or Wednesday to the whole list so that  
> people have it in time for Thursday parties.
>
> The user profiles are a harder question in some ways I think.  But  
> I don't like migrating to a community platform (i.e. Tribe) that
